reviews.reviewText: Does the job! grounds aren't as fine as a would desire but hey, its thirteen bucks!
Easy to use and clean. Versatile and precise.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very easy to use and works well for grinding for our ...
reviews.reviewText: Very easy to use and works well for grinding for our French Press. Affordable option for those who need a grinder with settings beyond drip!
Actually grinds to the right consistancy -nuff said
small and works great, I like it that has different settings.

At first I thought it was broken because it wasnt grinding but the bowl was just slightly off of alignment. Was able to fix really easily by holding it in place. Slightly inconvenient but it works great so cant complain too much!

This has a few bells and whistles normally not found on coffee grinders. We don't use the bells and whistles but they can be handy if you have the need. Grinds beans fast and the way you want them.

Update:1/21/13

Had to return the item because parts inside the grind chamber just kept chipping off. Durability is quite questionable. Changed my rating from a 5 star to 3 star.
Is a tad bit loud but nothing I would not expect From a grinder. I only use it for grinding up dried pepper pods

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice features and clever mechanism to get all grounds out ...
reviews.reviewText: Nice features and clever mechanism to get all grounds out of the grinding chamber. But no matter what grind setting I use, how full the chamber is or if I repeat the grind a couple times, the grind is never even. There are always coarsely chopped beans that have hardly been ground, even on the fine setting.
Good
Great, sent one to my parents in Asia

I love it! It gives me grind options and correct measurements for my coffee. Small enough to keep on counter for daily use. Having a super fresh cup of coffee in the morning make the day go better.

Great buy!
Product stopped working after second use. Light comes on, but the blade won't turn. Past the return date for Amazon, so I can even return it. It's a piece of junk. Do not buy!

I use it every other day almost. And I have espresso machine and French press , so I have tried fine and coarse grind, both worked really well. Small in size, perfect for small portion of coffee. At least works for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: this works great. Gets a really consistent grind and the auto ...
reviews.reviewText: Still slightly confused about what the cup amount selection does exactly. However, as a grinder, this works great. Gets a really consistent grind and the auto shutoff keeps the motor from burning up. Great product.
Great coffe grinder. I like my coffe ground very fine and this machine does the job

Perhaps the best grinder I have used at this price ... and at prices far higher. Easy to set for the number of cups and the type of grind wanted; just set it, press the button and hold until it stops. Easier to clean than any other grinder I have used. Can you tell ... I REALLY like this one.
The grind settings are nice feature for something too have such a cheap price.
Grinder works well, has lots of power and easy to clean.
Ive been using my grinder daily for a year and a half now, and it has been great. It doesnt take up much space, isnt too loud, and is always trustworthy. Its also very easy to take apart and clean
This grinder does not grind coffee evenly plus coffee gets stuck in the bottom of the catch bowl and aggravating to clean.
Love this grinder. I bought this same grinder over 10 years ago and it still works. I bought the new one so I can grind herbs and spices. These things are workhorses and mine has lasted for years

I like this because it helps not making a coffee ground mess every time you need it. Very handy to use. I like the little built in scraper that get all the coffee out. It fixes all the short comings of the reliable but messy Braun it replaced.

As a con, it never really shuts off. The little lights stay on, so I unplug it between uses.
Great coffee grinder. Does a great job. Well made.
Is silent and it works perfectly.

Works as advertised. My only complaint, which is mild, is that the cleaner twist doesn't perform as well as expected or advertised. Otherwise I love this grinder! I use it for my drip as well as my press.

Nice compact design, does a good job of grinding the coffee beans in a quick and consistent manner. My only complaint is that it is a bit difficult to twist the grinder bin on and off after each use. Perhaps after regular use this will loosen up a little and become easier to remove. In any case it's a decent little coffee grinder that looks and performs well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Arrived on time and as advertised.

super easy to use and perfect for us
perfect.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Little Coffee Grinder That Could
reviews.reviewText:
You know the little engine that could? Well, this is the little coffee grinder that could.

I have had this item for over 4 years. I use it for everything but coffee beans. I have used it for making pesto, grinding nuts, spices and seeds, making buckwheat flour and lentil flour. Well, after all the abuse I have given it, a part of the plastic cleaning chamber broke. So I snapped it off since it was loose. But it still worked after that. Then the motor gave out. Lucky for me, my dad fixed it. Now my grinder is working just like before.

I think this is a great grinder. I especially like that you can detach the bowl from the rest of the machine so it makes it easy to clean. Not many models of coffee grinders have that feature. All in all, if this one completely gave out, I would go and buy another one. Or perhaps I would buy this one http://amzn.to/1zqKqPC since it looks durable and it comes with 2 stainless steel bowls as opposed to the Mr. Coffee which is made of plastic. I'll let you know if I make that purchase....

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Value Grinder. I bought 2 more later!
reviews.reviewText: Whats not to like. Works great for coffee or spices. Adjustable grind. Easy to fill and dump. Relatively easy to clean.

Utilizing this coffee grinder for a use other than what is was intended for (grinding up dry dog food), it is just ok. I'm fairly sure that dry dog food is generally softer and lends itself better to grinding than hard coffee beans however, I find that I have had to replace this grinder on an average of every six months due to a snapping off of the grinding blades which renders the entire machine useless. I also found that the "Chamber Maid Cleaning System", although a good idea in theory, was comtributing to the early snapping of the grinding blades as the blades would sometimes get caught up in the plastic chamber maid inside the grinding cup. Now when I receive a new grinder, I automatically snap off the plastic "chamber maid" from the cup which seems to have prolonged the life of the blades. But I do believe the problem arises because the blades get dull too quickly.

Not being able to replace just the grinder cup, I've had no choice but to reorder the entire grinder. Luckily it is not an extremely expensive item and, when it's working, it serves my purpose nicely. Contrary to the fragility of the grinding blades, I have never had an issue with the motor burning out. The motor seems to be of a solid design. The breakage of the grinding blades is the reason for the three star ("it's okay") rating.

But the coffee grinder just a little bit over a month ago used it four times and now it doesnt grind coffee or herbs ...was working wonderfully the first few times now the grinder makes a loud noise and doesnt even grind anything ??

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after a few months
reviews.reviewText: Smaller design. I liked that the grinder popped off for cleaning but it stopped working after a few months. Not meant for an everyday coffee drinker.

A quick background of me as a coffee drinker: I use a french press to brew my coffee thus I require a coarse grind for my coffee.

This grinder (even when filled to its max setting, set for coarse, and set for its minimum number of cups) cannot produce a coarse grind. The closest it can get is barely any coarser than a medium grind. It also produces a lot of dust which is not good for any type of coffee makers. These aspects combined make it a poor choice for french press users.

Also the grind is not very consistent, so it would not be horribly great for use with an espresso machine either.

This being said, the medium grind it can produce is good enough to use with standard drip coffee makers. If you only use drip machines and do not expect to try any other coffee brewing methods, then this is not that bad for the price, but other than that, there are better grinders on the market.

You dump the beans in, set how much you put in and how fine you want to grind it, then just push the button til it stops. Super easy and grinds perfectly. When you're done, just twist it off and throw it in the dishwasher. If it ever breaks (which I really don't think it will), I'd buy another one in a heartbeat.

I had used the Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric Coffee Grinder with Chamber Maid Cleaning System at a friends house and was so impressed I ordered my own. The grinder automatically stops based on the number of cups you choose (4-12) and how fine you want the coffee (coarse-fine). In my opinion, the system runs a bit too long and over grinds the coffee if you choose the appropriate expected number of cups and grind. For a full pot of 12 cups, I choose medium grind and 8 cups. The cleanup system is very good, it cleans well. And the lid and grind chamber as removable for cleaning. The cord is cleverly hidden around the bottom of the grinder.

To start: I really wanted to like this coffee grinder. I like to think of myself as an educated buyer, and I do not make impulse purchases that often. I've read most of the reviews on this grinder, and I found that the gripes were true, and than some.
a) Very cumbersome engineering of the lid. The detachable chamber has two "lids", the large one with a black ring that comes off, and another "flap-lid" that sits on top of that one. I guess the idea is to use the flip lid to pour your beans, and than to take the bigger lid when pouring the grounds out? Not sure about logic behind this redundancy.
b) The "Chamber Maid" system is an excellent idea...but in reality it is more in the way than being useful. It is in the way when you trying to put the lid on the chamber, and than the prongs are in the way when you are trying to clean the chamber (since no, they do NOT clean the chamber totally clean. I am a bit fastidious, and I like to start the grinding without mixing old with fresh coffee. Yes, its a minute thing, but still...)
c)To line the lid with the activation button is not for the impatient. The activation button presses on the miniscule "safety" pin that is the size of the tip of the pen. One hair tho the left or to the right - its a no-go.
d) the shear amount of pressure on the "Go" button needed to activate the grinder is mind-boggling. I cannot see an elderly person being able to operate this.
d) Noisy. By far the loudest of all the coffee grinder I had. I know this comes with the territory, but still, my previous GE was NOT this loud.
e) Cable length&stowage. Again, reviews about the short cable are true. Not that big of an issue, but still. There is not-so-user-friendly way to coil the cable back in the base, but it is such a pain that I leave mine out.

Positives: excellent Fit&Finish. The material quality is good, it does not feel cheeply made. There are settings on the side to pre-set your grind and time, but after few trials, I learn to ignore them, and just keep grinding to my own accord until I get the finesse of the ground coffee the way I want it.

Conclusion: Over-engineered beyond being user-friendly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful Coffee Grinder - Price is Right!
reviews.reviewText: I'm a newbie at coffee grinding, but received 3 bags (different flavors) as a gift for Christmas. This arrived very quickly, is easy to use (the instructions are very clear) and really easy to clean. I like my coffee at a full flavor so where it indicates to use the medium grind for our drip coffee maker, I usually go the "fine grind" route. Just put the beans in (not past the middle line), indicate how many cups you're making by pushing the top button to the selected amount up to 12 cups (4-8-12), select the grind, then press the top and hold. It will stop on its own when it's finished. Easy as pie! The price was right for us!
Picked this up to save a little money on coffee. It grinds everything very well and gets the job done. Can't complain.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't pay more for nothing; mine stopped working after 2 months
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this coffee grinder based on its rating and reviews, and I paid more for it than I normally would for a coffee grinder; however, not only was this coffee grinder nothing special, it was poorly designed, difficult to use, and then it stopped working after only 2 months of moderate use, and I had to go and buy yet another coffee grinder! Only this time, I learned from my mistake and simply bought the cheapest one I could find. My lesson: A coffee grinder doesn't need to be fancy; all it needs to do is grind beans, so don't be stupid like me and fall for a bunch of whistles and bells that don't really do anything. The second coffee grinder I bought was a Toastmaster 1119, your basic no frills grinder -it was half the price, it's much easier to use, and so far, it's lasted twice as long (I've had it about 6 or 7 months now and it's working fine).
I hope this helps someone! :)

reviews.reviewText: I bought my coffee grinder a few years ago. We used it about four times when we first got in (over the course of a couple of weeks) and then more or less forgot about it. I recently bought some coffee beans that required grinding and so I pulled this little guy out again. After only filling it with beans to the max line mark and holding down the grind button so that it could do a medium course grind, the coffee that resulted was inconsistently ground and I noticed the coffee grinder was very hot - almost smoking. I tipped the grinds into another container for storage purposes and re-filled the unit to the max line again, to grind a second batch. After the second grind was over, the unit was visibly smoking (I was concerned it was on fire on the inside) and emitting a noxious burning plastic smell. I quickly shut off the power, pulled the cord out of the socket and moved the coffee grinder to the top of my stainless steel sink so that if it was in fire, I'd be able to act quickly and safely. I assume the fuse blew because it eventually stopped smoking, but after only using this machine a half a dozen times or so, I'm very disappointed this ever made it to market. It's a health and safety concern and in my opinion, all units with the faulty fuse should have been recalled. I would not buy from Mr Coffee again in future as I can only surmise the brand is unethical and produces rubbish quality goods.

reviews.reviewTitle: My Mr Coffee, coffee bean grinder.
reviews.reviewText: This is the 3rd coffee grinder I have gone through in the past year since I started grinding my own coffee beans. With the first 2 grinders the motors failed, both within a very short period of time. Up to this point My Mr Coffee grinder has worked very well. It is a lot quieter then the other two and it seems I get a better grind. It must be because this grinder offers 3 different settings for grinding. I get a more consistent grind with this grinder especially in the morning when I've forgotten tho grind my coffee beans he night before. Not real impressed with the Chamber maid cleaning system, although I get less waste, for me that is not a big issue. I think I have had this grinder for about 5 months without any break downs. I still need more time to say this product is absolutely superior over the other two,it certainly was less expensive of the three grinders. I also think that the white and black one should have been offered for the same price.
Best grinder for price point out there.
Excellent grinder with nice settings for quantity of beans grinded and coarseness levels of grinds. The removable grind chamber makes clean up a snap. Great grinder for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: NOT a burr grinder as categorized...
reviews.reviewText:
**Update: more than a year later, Amazon has still not moved this product out of the incorrect category. Buyer beware and minus two more stars. **

NOTE: This item is improperly listed in the "Electric Burr Grinders" section of Amazon. It is NOT a burr grinder, it is a blade grinder! Yes, careful inspection of ALL the pictures would have told me this as well, but I assumed it was properly categorized. Minus 1 star.

Reviewing it as a blade grinder, it works fine... and is pretty cheap. But I probably would have just picked up another Krups grinder if I wanted a blade grinder. The 'automatic' controls on it are a bit hokey... You set the grind and number of cups, but sill have to hold down the button the entire time. It just shuts off automatically. Honestly if you've ground more than a dozen batches of beans you have a feel for how long to grind by sound alone, so it really just makes it more work to check/set the device every time or have it shut off early. Minus a second star.

OK, it was only $14, so I'll quit my complaining and keep it anyway, but Amazon, please move this grinder to the proper section!

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent product. Just a little unlike the AC cord ...
reviews.reviewText:
I found this excellent product, I love how it works and the results, totally recomended to home barista amateurs.
Just a little unlike the AC cord its small and I need an extra extension (outleet-strip) to conect to the electricity.
Excellent

reviews.reviewTitle: Has too many parts which feel flimsy and a good chance of something
reviews.reviewText: Don't have much confidence in this grinder. Has too many parts which feel flimsy and a good chance of something breaking
The worst coffee grinder I have ever owned even on a fine setting it leaves half beans untouched

reviews.reviewTitle: There is no possible way to get a great cup of coffee out of the beans being ground ...
reviews.reviewText: Absolutely no consistency on grind size. There is no possible way to get a great cup of coffee out of the beans being ground in this thing.
Piece of crap...No more Mr. Coffee for me anymore! Boycotting all your products!

reviews.reviewTitle: I've never been more disappointed at an Amazon product
reviews.reviewText: Never worked. I've never been more disappointed at an Amazon product. Don't Buy!

reviews.reviewTitle: Got as gift for my Girlfriend
reviews.reviewText: I bought this as a gift for my girlfriend for Christmas and she loves it and uses it everyday lol

I am very disappointed in the grind quality. After following the instructions I end up with unevenly ground beans. Not good. Also, the machine is not nearly as easy to clean as the product description suggests.

reviews.reviewTitle: This coffee snob is not happy
reviews.reviewText: Cumbersome, complicated, annoying...shall I go on? It grinds, but what a pain in the neck it is to operate. Get something better!
Good product, arrived on time. I recommend it
It broke after using it twice.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mr. Coffee grinder not for fine coffee
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this unit to grind coffee for expresso and found it does not grind to a "fine" ground. It has a "fine" setting but does not come close to actually pulling it off. The "fine" setting just grinds longer than the "course" and "medium" setting. Very disapointed.
He hasn't used it yet, but so far he's enchanted with it. I will alter this once he has used it with how it works. Hopefully well!
Have not used yet but expect great things:)

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't work and can't return or exchange
reviews.reviewText:
I just opened this up to use it and it doesn't work. Of course, now I can't find a way to return, exchange or get a hold of anyone to help me.
I am VERY. VERY disappointed!

I'm not a big user of this product, so imagine my surprise when after 1 year, the plastic bracket on the inside BROKE. I had to dig through coffee grounds to pick out the plastic parts. I really expected a coffee grinder carrying the Mr. Coffee brand to last longer than a year. Disappointing. And of course it's now too late to exchange it.
This product broke on the first use and could not be returned. No kidding. The motor is junk. Amazon return is junk too!!

Bugger ! Lessoned learnt , always find out the volts an hertz when purchasing electrical items.
This grinder shorted in a cloud of smoke when used using Australian 240V / 50 Hz.
Maybe make these ratings more promenant in the advertisement.........
Not working

I read through a few reviews and didn't see this problem so I don't know if I'm unique or doing something wrong. I got this for Christmas last year so have been using it almost daily for about nine months. I have no complaints about its function and I live having a fresh ground cup in the morning. My problem is that on the outside of the cup, there is plastic that goes over the stainless steel base. Over the months, water has been able to get in between that plastic and the base but hasn't really been able to air out the way it needs to. As a result, I'm seeing rust and possibly mold growing in those spaces. It's on the outside of the cup, nowhere near where the actual coffee goes, but it bothers me that it's happening as I like to keep my things looking nice and clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: I do not recommend this item
reviews.reviewText: This coffee grinder has a cord that is less than one foot long. It is a nuisance to try to use. I do not recommend this item because of the cord.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a grinder but a blunt blade bean cracker. .
reviews.reviewText:
Blunt blade bean breaker. Not a grinder by any definition but the crappiest of blenders. If you want whole beans mixed in with fine powder and every size in between for your french press, it's great. If you want your grounds to have the bloom of the Sahara in August, it's great.
If you actually want consistent and appropriately sized grounds, get a conical burr grinder. A hand grinder is well worth it if you're going for cheap, self-made coffee and not much more expensive than this waste of $20. It's really not much work or time hand grinding. Unless you can't use your arms. I spent almost as much time trying to get  decent grounds out of this as I did just doing it the right way with a hand grinder. Much, much happier tossing this blunt blade blender for even a $40 hand grinder.
This blender also sounds like, well, a blender. It's Loud and if you tend to hibernate with bears and Sandy Cheeks like myself and if you wake them up without a mug of coffee..... Well, just do yourself a favor and get a hand grinder.
Pros: Easy to be lazy. Cheap. Easy to push the button down once you get the sucker lined up right.

reviews.reviewTitle: Returning to this after bad burr grinder experience
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned this grinder for many years, but recently I decided to improve my coffee game by upgrading to a burr grinder. Coffee lovers will tell you that you should use a burr grinder to get consistently sized grounds, which promotes even extraction and makes the coffee taste the way it should. Well, it wasn't an upgrade at all! On the coarsest setting, the Chefman burr grinder I "upgraded" to produced a lot more fine powder than this Mr. Coffee grinder does, and much more bitter coffee.

Don't get me wrong. I'm not saying this makes completely consistent coffee grounds. You'd probably have to spend over $200 for a highly-rated burr grinder for that. (However, I've never had the experience other reviewers have mentioned of having a whole bean that wasn't ground at all.)

My point is that this is a competent little grinder that takes up very little counter space and is very easy to clean. I'm still on the hunt for a better grinder, but until I find it, I'll feel no shame in continuing to use this one. Let the coffee snobs look down their noses at me

reviews.reviewTitle: NOT a precision grinder, just a basic blender
reviews.reviewText:
The description says that this has multiple settings in order to adjust how fine or coarse the grind is. However, all it does is set a timer for how long the grinder automatically switches off. You basically have to randomly try combinations of buttons until you get what you want.

This is not a burr grinder. It is a blade blender, the size of a magic bullet blender. Shell out another ten bucks and just buy a Magic Bullet blender and use it to grind your coffee.

The instructions say choose your grind fine/medium/coarse and choose how many cups you are making. If I choose Fine and 4 cups, which is what my stovetop espresso percolator uses, I get giant chunks of coffee bean amid very coarse grounds. I have to put it on the 12 cups setting and run it a couple times to get a proper fine grind for four cups of espresso.

I would return this if I hadnt already used it and buy a burr grinder, or a magic bullet.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not good for making garlic powder
reviews.reviewText:
I use grinders such as this for grinding dehydrated items into a fine powder. Frankly, the simple Mr. Coffee grinder I used for years yet can't find now did a very good job. I purchased it because it said on the box that it could be used for spices, yet the instruction booklet says not to use it for spices. Hmmm, something was lost in the translation from Chinese. But the booklet was correct. Use another product for spices.
Specifically I had to dig several partially ground pieces out of the powder. They ground fine when put back in by themselves. And that Chamber Maid cleaning system might work for coffee grounds but not for spices, and the system doesn't touch the lid. I'll clean it then donate it to Goodwill.

I have one of those. Bought it a few years ago.
Threw it into the garbage.

This is a typical over-engineered "grinder" developed by some tea drinking soy free gluten free whatever nerd.
The product marketing department must have decided to sell this useless marvel it needs flashing LEDs and a timer including a multi turn and twist how-can-we-make-a-simple-thing-more-complicated-and-cumbersome lid lock, cup lock bla bla...
...out of which you never will be able to "pour" the coffee grind but mess up all surroundings for sure.
The tea nerd engineer forgot some facts. (to many to list)

Plus, as an added bonus you ingest fine ground plastic!
The plastic arms (or scrapers) that are supposed to "clean" the bowl get thinner and thinner and then all break.
Of course! smacking cracked hard coffee beans onto plastic the softer will give! Duh!
Not sandblasting but coffee blasting!
Enjoy your plasticized coffee, yummi, "insoluble fiber"...!

My advice and recommendation: "Keep it simple stupid", buy a simple straight forward Krups or Braun handy little forever functioning little coffee grinder to help you start your day!
Even better, get a manual one, a hand cranked one. Starts (and makes) your day with a little positive ritual!

Love this little grinder! I've lost count of how many years I've had it, but I know it's been almost 10 years. It's stayed with me during 2 break ups, and 5 moves. I use this daily! On bad days, twice. It's a little on the loud side, but, it works great. Has a few different settings so you can decide how much you want it to grind. The top part can go in the dish washer, and I've never had an issue with the blade. It still works like it did the day I got it from Wal*Mart. It is the perfect little grinder. When mine does decide to die, I will be buying a new one for sure.

reviews.reviewTitle: No Trouble After about a Decade
reviews.reviewText: I've had one of these for like 10 years and I probably fix a pot or two a week with it. I've not had any trouble from it. The grind is about what you would expect from a blade grinder under $20: as even as it needs to be, although not quite as even as is probably ideal. The best part of it is that it has a way to customize the grind according to the amount of cups and the size coarseness desired, although I typically set it for more cups than I'm actually going to brew. Cleans easily enough if you're not a jackass. What more could you want out of cheap electronics?

I bought this grinder in 2006 when my MIL told me her horror story of going to grind coffee she purchased at a local chain store and seeing maggots in the grinder. Money was tight and I had a Gevalia coffee maker (the one they used to give you free for trying their coffee) and I needed a fine grind. This was the cheapest coffee grinder Kmart had so I bought it. It did a great job making a fine grind. After I moved, I had minimal counter space. I switched to a French press coffee maker so I could put it in the cupboard to recoup the three feet of counter space I do have. Now I need a course grind. I fill it up with coffee completely, set it to 8-10 cups, and shake it while I press the grind button. If I don't shake it, there are chunks of coffee beans mixed in. Maybe more work than buying a new one, but it is 11 years old and still works. That in and of itself is amazing in this day and age - especially considering it only cost about $10 at the time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Everything kept breaking until it died.
reviews.reviewText: This is a really bad coffee grinder in my experience. I've had this for about 4 few years and it just got worse over time until the motor just died. Within 6 months of buying this grinder the top button used to make the grinder start broke off and we've been using pens to operate for the last 4 years. The blades dulled after about 1 year and it took a long time to get things finely ground. It was almost impossible to clean out the nooks and crannies of the lid if you want to grind something other than coffee. With the grind settings on the side - the buttons became stuck so you couldn't change the coarseness of the grind and the words wore off so I had no idea what setting it was on. The lid and twist off grind cup were very annoying to use. Everything has to be lined up like a food processor to work. It's not hard to figure out, but when you're stumbling around in the morning trying to make coffee it's difficult with your limited motor skills. This was the most hated kitchen tool I owned. I'm really glad it died so I can get a different brand.

got this coffee grinder because people kept recommending I buy whole coffee beans and grind it myself instead of buying it ground and the flavor wears off. I'm glad I did. grinding fresh beans everyday to make coffee is a delight. been using this for a month and so far it does the job. it cleans easily with a sponge and you have 3 grinding settings for your convenience.

This has been an excellent grinder. I had this grinder when I was married, we went through two to three pots of coffee a day, it's less now since it's only me. My ex-wife took position of the grinder and coffee pot. Thought I could without for awhile but I missed my coffee. Checked reviews on grinders and coffee makers (a Mr. Coffee as well) and learned I couldn't beat what I had. The Krups is nice but I would really miss the removable top (which holds the grounds). The one my wife took with her was at least 8-10 years old and it was still doing it's job. I thought I would try something different but none offered the the features and results that this one did and as a prior user, I knew it to be a fact. People complaining about the cord? it's wound up underneath the grinder - pull it out to a length you prefer! The grind results? c'mon, this unit will produce a nice fine, medium or course grind using the settings and depending on how long you grind it. I do usually give it a jiggle when grinding to ensure all beans are ground - this is mostly needed because I use a lot of beans and I do surpass the max "do not fill above this line" mark for a 12 cup coffee maker (what can I say? I like a strong brew, I'm Norwegian) - this is an excellent grinder especially for the money.

I had been using this grinder for a few months then the other morning the black plastic "cleaning system" was ground into my coffee. I had to throw out all of the coffee grinds in the cup due to all of the black plastic in it! Also, the grinder never gave me any consistent grind and it always left unground or partially ground beans. Will be buying a manual ceramic burr grinder to replace this waste of plastic. Tried to find a replacement cup for it because I really did not want to send so much plastic & electrical parts to the dump. No luck. The cup is no longer made or available according to Mr. Coffee's website. Caveat emptor!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Grinder, Annoying Lid/Bowl Locking Mechanism
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this coffee grinder faithfully for about a year.

Pros:
- It does what it's supposed to do! It can grind coffee from coarse to fine.
- You can grind a pretty large amount of coffee beans at once (up to 10 cups' worth).

Cons:
- The cord is short. I knew this when I bought it, and I didn't think it would bother me. Well, it turns out that a short cord can make things very inconvenient.
- The grinder has 3 parts: the base, the 'bowl' to hold coffee beans, and the lid. It's a pain to put all three parts together! You see those words and lines on the bowl and the lid for locking and fitting the pieces together? It is NOT a breeze. Sure, it only takes an extra 10-20 seconds to figure out than traditional lids, but when I'm making coffee in the morning, those 20 seconds can be extremely irritating (especially before you've had your coffee!). I also did not realize how annoying this was until I used my roommate's Krups coffee grinder - you literally just put the lid on top and push down the button. After that, I just haven't found the patience to fiddle with the bowl and the lid every morning. I've experienced how much easier life can be and now I can't go back!

Summary: This will get the job done, but the usability isn't great. Get the Krups grinder instead for the same price... your future self will be happier and you won't even know it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great coffee grinder for the price!
reviews.reviewText: I have ground my coffee at the store, but then always felt it went stale while sitting at home. Decided to invest in this grinder, and loved the price point and excellent reviews. I have been very happy with the grinder, and have owned it for approximately 3 months. There are 3 settings depending on the coarseness you need your grinders for your coffee maker, and you can grind quite a bit at one time. I do often have a little residue that gets caught around the blades when finished, but nothing that a spoon can't get out. Easy to wash, easy to use and does an excellent job. Would highly recommend!

The settings give you options for different grinds, they look all the same to me at the end, maybe slightly more course or slightly more fine, but marginally. After grinding maybe 5 pounds of coffee over the course of a month or 2, grinder mysteriously stops grinding coffee. I don't mean like the mechanics burnt out, like the lights are on and press the button and nothing. Had my girlfriend try her hand at it and we played around with it for about an hour, to no avail, and the grinder went down the garbage shoot.

reviews.reviewTitle: A great spice grinder but careful what you grind
reviews.reviewText: It's a wonderful grinder for the purposes I use it for. The first one I got at a thrift store and that lasted me a couple years and the only reason it died is because someone dropped it real hard. When that one died I got another one. Keep in mind I don't grind whole beans in it. On the off chance any coffee goes in it, it is already medium grind so I use it to make decent espresso. I generally use it as a spice grinder or a quick mincer. cons: DO NOT LET ANY WATER GET NEAR THIS THING. A small drop of it hit the bottom area of it on accident and I think it shorted. It now hisses at me and makes small wisps of acrid smoke come out of it... I'm afraid I may be moving on to grinder #3

reviews.reviewTitle: Its a Coffee Bean Obliterator, it doesn't actually grind anything. But it does a good job of obliterating the beans.
reviews.reviewText:
They should call it a coffee obliterator. It makes coffee grinds by beating the crap out of the beans with steel blades moving at hundreds of mph. The lack of actual grinding action results in grinds that fail to produce coffee as good as the beans actually are. The grinds lack the oils, aroma, and flavor of fresh properly ground beans. But if you're "coffee-powered" like me, and you just need that first cup as soon as you get up, this "grinder" does make you a cup of coffee really fast with little effort and time. Wake you up enough to make real coffee with your real grinder that makes coffee as good as the beans actually are.

Anyway, I have been using this as my primary go-to grinder for several years. It is a good product when you want ground coffee with minimal effort and time spent. It is easy to use, it has automatic timers for different amounts of grind and fineness of grind, it makes consistent size of grinds, and it is easy to clean.

Despite it lacking any grinding action, i give it 5 stars because it is a damn good obliterator. You put anything in it, it'll make "grinds" for you.

I got this as a gift this week. It's much noisier than the Proctor and Silex one I've had for 4 or 5 years, still going strong, despite the beating me and my two year old have given it every single morning. We bang on the lid with a spoon, knock it against the counter to get all the coffee in the middle. I'm not sure this Mr. Coffee would survive a week in my kitchen.

This one had too many parts, making it feel flimsy. Certain things had to be in the right spot, clicked in the right way, held centered while I ground it. The lid for pouring flopped and clicked around and made pouring a very messy endeavor. I tried it and my husband thought I must be doing it wrong so he tried and we both got coffee grounds on the counter and in the sink. It's much easier to just scoop coffee out of the basket with a spoon, making the floppy lid pointless.

It's much louder and larger than my Proctor Silex grinder. I prefer the quite hum of mine to the loud, plasticy whir this makes.

The last nail in the coffin was the "wind up" cord that took way too long and was a pain to shove in the hole. My current grinder winds up with a manual twist of the lid and takes about three seconds. No motorized parts, nothing to break. That's probably why it's lasted me so long! I'll be returning this Mr. Coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Send me the purchase price for this product and you will get the same satisfaction!
reviews.reviewText: I was looking on Amazon for a grinder to replace our 20 year old Braun. My wife suggested that I just go to Wallyworld and get a grinder. I took her advise and bought this grinder. It was not the cheapest they had, but it seemed to have some clever features. Well, about a week later, the plastic wipers in the 'Chamber Maid' bowl ground up with the beans. After picking the plastic bits out of the ground coffee, the grinder still worked...for a while. The grinder operation is a pain in the a... The removable bowl has to be inserted using a registration mark to line up grooves and rotated to a certain point, then the lid has to be inserted by using a different registration mark and rotated a different amount to a certain point for the grinder to operate. After dialing in the grind and number of cups, you hold the run button down untill the grinder stops. Then you can remove the bowl and use the flip lid and pour spout to pour some of the coffee out somewhat accurately. Then you unscrew the flip lid from the bowl (be sure to do this over the sink or trashcan to catch ground coffee caught in the groove between the lid and the bowl) and after tapping the bowl against the sink, pour the rest of the grind into your filter holder. All my wife and I wanted was a good cup of morning coffee...Please!!! Bought a Krups on Amazon and now we're happy.

I've had this grinder for about two years now. It's held up okay. There are three plastic bars along the insides that help you remove the grinds stuck to the sides, and quickly one of them broke. Now all three are broken and I'm buying a different grinder.

There are multiple settings that allow you to select the coarseness of the grind, but I always select the most fine because I'm not sure why someone would want coarsely ground coffee. The text above the coarseness setting and the size setting on quickly wore off, so you have to work from memory for which setting is which.

The grinder grinds flax seeds and chopped pecans well. However, I don't recommend it because there is a small metal bowl at the bottom of the plastic container where the blade actually sits. There is space between the metal bowl and the outer plastic, and anything you grind can and will get stuck between them. It's actually impossible to clean, even with water, soaking, dish washer, etc., because the space is so very thin. It's quite gross/unsanitary. (Though I kept using it . . . What does that say about me?)

Anyway, it's an ok grinder. Not the best, but I guess it does the job.

I really have loved this grinder since I got it second hand. It has worked very well and I have had no issues. I just read a couple of reviews about the cord and am laughing at myself right now!! I have had this thing for at least 2 years and have been using about 15 inches worth of cord. When I'm done using it I wind the cord around the body of the grinder to store and I could have been actually using the winder on the bottom! LOL to all you who didn't know about the cord thing don't feel dumb! There's more than a few confused by it!! :D I would recommend this to anyone who doesn't have a lot of $$ to spend on a fancy grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Look for something else... Very hard to clean.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this as a last minute item from a box store and not Amazon. It works ok but the grind doesn't seem consistent at all and is very noisy.

My biggest complaint is how it claims to be easy to clean but is not.. at all. The cleaning mechanism (really three cheap plastic blades) that rotates inside the chamber gets a little of the coffee off the sides but leaves a dusting. The chamber itself does not come apart so you are left trying to clean out the bottom where all the coffee settles, which is a huge pain to dry afterwards. Then the bottom of the chamber has a metal "bowl" that is covered in plastic. The gap between the two allows water to bleed in and there isn't any way to get it out, which leads to rust and mold. Not a good design feature at all. Save your money on this and look for something better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great and lasts for a good while, too.
reviews.reviewText:
We just got a replacement IDS77 for our old IDS77. I love this grinding mill and will be very sad when (and if) it is finally discontinued. It's great not to have to dig the coffee out of a mill with a finger and have to clean your finger and fingernail off afterwards. The "chamber maid" system does it for you. It always leaves super-fine grinds behind, stuck to the metal chamber--just as does any mill--but I just leave them there and they don't affect anything that I can tell. The vanes handily remove your freshly ground coffee. A couple of spins and a couple of taps and you're done. I enjoy being able to just remove the bowl and transfer to the coffee maker instead of dragging the whole mill over there. I clean the bowl and lid maybe once a year.

I've seen reviews here that complain about the plastic vanes getting eaten away by the blades. I honestly don't know how this could happen, since the blade doesn't come close to the vanes. It didn't happen with my old mill and it isn't happening with the new one. I've carefully examined the old and new mills and can't see any differences in engineering or weight. The plastic parts might be made from a slightly different formula or process, but they work fine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works ok, but a few drawbacks
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder a couple of months ago to replace my old one that was dying after many years. I thought it looked cool and the features seemed to be good. I'm used to a regular grinder without any frills, like the Capresso and the Krups I had before it, that ground my coffee just as I liked it, depending on how long I ground it.
The Mr. Coffee grinder has a "do not fill above this line"mark. It takes such a small amount of beans, so there's no way you could grind enough in one batch to make a full pot of coffee. This I found annoying. I don't keep it plugged in on the counter, so each time I plugged it in I had to re-set everything; number of cups, grind quality, before using. Too much of a pain, and I'd rather just have one that simply does the job.
Lastly, today when I used it, the plastic pieces inside that help clean out the coffee grounds, was in pieces when I opened it up. It had broken up and pieces were in the coffee. Bad design. Cheaply made. I suppose I can use it without that piece, but I think I'm going to go and buy a good and simple grinder as I had before.
I wouldn't recommend this product.

My husband and I recently purchased a Keurig coffee maker and decided to off set the cost of cofee by using ground coffee instead of the pre-packaged K-cups. We first purchased the filter for the Keurig and tried the regular store bought ground coffee. The results were not good. We then decided to ground our own coffee which led us to buying this grinder. After reading the favorable reviews and noticing the Consumer Reports approval for this grinder I decided to give it a try. I first attempted to grind the coffee on the "coarse" setting and didn't like the results at all. For me the coffee was more like coffee flavored water. I tried again. This time I used the medium setting for the recommeded 15 seconds and I was very pleased with the results. Because I like coffee with a little kick I decided to add a few more seconds to my grinding cycle. This gave me the perfect grind for my taste. All in all this is a great little grinder for a decent price. A note on the cleaning system. It isn't what I was expecting, but it works okay. It doesn't entirely clean the grinding chamber. You will have coffee residue after you use it. I just wanted a good cup of coffee and for me this grinder makes it happen.

I bought this grinder after my previous grinder stopped working after two solid years of perfect grinding.

I personally don't believe that a $300 grinder does anything magical to coffee beans that would justify paying such a high price for it, so I looked around for a good, cheap grinder to replace my first good, cheap grinder. This seemed to fit the bill. The price is great. I do like that it takes the guess work out of how long to grind, and it looks sleek sitting on the counter. You do have to hold the button down while grinding. However, I make 16 oz of coffee at a time, not a full 12-cup pot. That means I have to hold the button down for about 25 or 30 seconds. It's fine. My coffee always tastes great. There aren't ever any beans that didn't grind.

What I don't like about this grinder is how messy it is. My first grinder had a large domed lid and was all stainless steel inside. After being ground, the coffee just slid out with very few grinds sticking to the walls or the top of the grinder. The flat lid on this grinder catches tons of coffee and holds it in all the little cracks and crevices. The cleaning system inside (which is really just a couple of plastic bars that rotate around the cup, scraping the sides) just cause the coffee to clump up. Every time I use this grinder I have to take the small coffee brush that came with my first grinder and sweep the coffee off the lid, from under the blades, from around the cleaning bars, and then from around my counter where some of it has inevitably fallen as I tried to sweep out the grounds. It's irritating. So irritating that I'm online now looking for a replacement. I just don't have the extra four or five minutes each morning that this grinder requires to clean up.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works Great with a Little Experimenting for that Perfect Grind!
reviews.reviewText:
For under 20 bucks, it would not be fair to throw stones at this machine. I'm not going to compare this to some 150-dollar burr grinder. I am going to compare this, though, to the stale, old ground coffee you may be used to drinking. For such a small investment, I am now enjoying coffee far superior in both aroma and flavor. Huge, huge difference-very, very little money!

I run this grinder daily, sometimes as many as 4-5 times each day. I will grant the pre-programmed settings do not produce the results you might hope for. Many times, you need to come up with your own recipe to get a correct grind. This may result in you having to experiment running a second grind until you come up with a consistency that fits your machine. For example, I have it down pat what two settings I need to run the grinder on to produce a very fine grind for espresso. The final grind is very consistent and produces an excellent shot. I've also come up with a medium grind for my drip maker, and again, very acceptable.

Listen, if you're looking for 150-dollar quality in this 19-dollar grinder, you're barking up the wrong tree. If you're looking to improve the flavor of your daily coffee to a much higher level, then this is the best 19 bucks you'll spend today. For the money, this is grinder is a 5-star value.

reviews.reviewTitle: Chamber Maid Cleaning Cleaning is horrible!
reviews.reviewText:
Grinder motor works fine. I give this two stars because the chamber maid cleaning works great for about 3 months and really helps to scrape the fines off the chamber bottom and walls but it is made of thin, weak plastic strips that easily break. Once one of the three strips snaps off it is over! The other two will follow shortly and it's back to coffee fines building up on the bottom and using whatever apparatus that's handy to scrape them out. A messy and wasteful chore!

If $20 is all you have to spend then as I said, the motor is strong and has lasted me 1 1/2 years. Maybe just be mindful of the plastic chamber maid strips penchant for breaking and be very gentle with it and maybe they will last longer for you than they did for me. If you have more than $20 to spend then just spring for a conical burr grinder which is what I finally ended up springing for. I'm still waiting for it to arrive and then my Mr. Coffee grinder will be sold for $1 at my summer yard sale.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is a wonderful coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText: I placed this coffee grinder on my wish list and received it as a gift. It is a wonderful coffee grinder, however, folks should know, unlike the advertised remark in the comparison columns, this product ONLY grinds coffee beans. It does NOT grind spices, nuts or anything else.. This info, in one sentence, is only available in the booklet coming with the unit. I am hoping to clarify this ahead of time, for buyers who are looking for a multi-purpose grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is of a design that is mind-bogglingly stupid. It is way too complicated inside- grinds stick ...
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is of a design that is mind-bogglingly stupid . It is way too complicated inside- grinds stick to the mesh, so that you have to scrape them out with a spoon. It also has big plastic pieces that seem really arbitrary. They just get in the way when you are arduously trying to get any grinds out. The lid also removed AND hinges??? so grinds get stuck where it hinges and its akward to hold open while trying to get the GD beans out. IN ADDITION, the cord does not retract all the way into the bottom, even though the bottom is supposed to be cord storage.
It also has 8 buttons that dont seem to do much of anything. Why does a coffee grinder need so many buttons?
I hate it every morning.
I will be switching back to proctor-silex.

This is the worst coffee grinder I have ever purchased, very messy to empty and clean. If you set the grind to coarse it is still fine. I have had it 3 months and I am ready to just toss it. Cleaning it is the pits you cannot get all of the coffee out, no brush included so I have to fill it with water and spray it out let it air dry. Mr Coffee you are a quality brand, what happened with this one? Also putting it together to get it to grind is a hassle unless you have it on perfectly straight it won't operate, made out of cheap plastic makes this a chore. I have never written a negative review, but I totally hate this grinder.

we got ours at walmart which is actually 2 bucks more for the same model, I almost didnt buy this because our 200 dollar Mr Coffee machine just died after 3 years and it had a built in coffee grinder that dropped the grounds into the filter and then the water kicked on and brewed it. and I know 3 years is a long time but a coffee maker should last much longer than 3 years at that price point.

any way now we needed a new grinder, so made a stop at walmart and at first I almost went with the 14 dollar grinder by krups but then I saw this one had the multiple settings, and it does work well and not too noisy either, I like very dark roasted coffee and fine ground comes out with the most flavor....

now this doesnt feel cheap, its heavy, and it works well so far though I cant say how long I have had it work a week and it cleans very easy, the best feature by far is in the grinding area the bottom is plated with metal not plastic this means the oil will not set in the plastic making off put flavors over time this is very hard too find in coffee grinders below $100

This grinder is extraordinarily over-engineered. There are too many settings that don't seem to affect the grind. There are too many moving parts that don't help in any way with the grounds removal. There are too many options for opening it and taking it apart that don't improve the ease of use. The grinding always comes out uneven and then pours all over the counter when it's opened. The multitude of features were included to distinguish it from other similar products and get it off the shelves, without any care for functionality or thoughtful design. Do not buy this landfill fodder.

This is my first coffee grinder and it is great. Both my wife and I are coffee drinkers. Hot coffee for her and cold brew for me. This coffee grinder has settings for grinding that allows you to choose the number of cups and the type of grind. She needs a fine grind for her coffee and I need a coarse ground for mine. This grinder checks all of the boxes for what we need. I recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best at this price range, but the plastic Chamber Maid broke relatively quickly.
reviews.reviewText:
My wife and I have used this workhorse 2-4 times daily for about 2 years. Works as advertised, and there probably isn't a better coffee grinder in this price range.

Main problem: The plastic "chamber maid" broke relatively quickly. First, after about 6 months, it stopped rotating with the lid (so I would rotate it with my fingers after taking the lid off). Then, after about two years, it broke entirely, and needed to be pulled out of the chamber and tossed. The grinder now continues to work fine, but doesn't have the chamber maid feature to help keep the chamber from accumulating a lot of stale grounds.

My brother has the same product, and he had a similar experience -- the chamber maid plastic parts broke in less than a year of daily use.

I contacted Mr. Coffee to see if it is possible to replace the chamber (so that I don't have to buy a whole new grinder -- the motor still works fine). I was told that they do not sell the chamber as a replacement part. I guess not too surprising, since the whole thing is only $20.

This is the most complicated and aggravating grinder Ive ever had.

All its features just make it more difficult to use.

To set the grind, you have to cycle through various settings with two buttons (which then reset after use, meaning you have to go through it all again next time). The operation is then timed, but Ive never found the grind to be right, so have to activate it again and again. For espresso, the grind is horrible, resulting in both large particles and powder which then clogs my maker.

The manual makes it sound like the 3 long cord is a safety feature for the user, but in reality its just a super inconvenient, cost-cutting measure for them, requiring you to hover it in front of the outlet to use.

Grind compartment and its lid are full of nooks and crannies, so super messy are hard to get your coffee out.

reviews.reviewTitle: It still works and does a great job at grinding the beans as long as it's ...
reviews.reviewText: I just gave mine to someone that doesn't have one. I was given a burr mill grinder. I bought mine at Target for the same price posted here in 2012. It still works and does a great job at grinding the beans as long as it's not over filled. you can always scrape the sides down and continue grinding the stray beans. For 20 bucks It has paid for itself at least 50x over, considering what I was spending at the grocery store on small bags of beans. I now pay 15 bucks for 40oz 100% Colombian coffee and it lasts 2 months. Yes, it does taste better ground fresh. It is easy to clean and operate. I hope it lasts awhile in it's new home. I gave the guy a small coffee pot with the filters I didn't use. He's going to save a lot of money making it himself, and will be safer than walking to Quik Trip for his 2 cups a day. This is still 20 bucks and still works great 5 years later. I highly recommend this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and easy to clean
reviews.reviewText: I have had this coffee grinder for about two years now, and feel that I can give it an honest review. For the cost, it does an excellent job. I am not a coffee expert by any means, but I do know the type of coffee that I like. I brew my coffee in a French press, and therefore need coarse ground coffee which I had difficulty finding locally already ground. This grinder does a fine job of planning the type of coffee that I need for my French press. It is easy to clean and easy to use. What more could you ask for?

Got this grinder, lasted about a year. Who in the world would design a grinder that requires you to hold down lid to grind? Cant walk away or do other thing while grinding. Stupid design, for a better design it should have a button you push on when grinding and off when not to include a locking lid that jus doesnt flip up. The removable twist cup is the only good part in the design of this grinder & maybe the price.

I'm sure this would do fine at grinding coffee beans, but I was using it to encapsulate placentas and it broke on the very first day. My old cheap coffee grinder does a much better job, even if it is harder to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder, but not for everyone
reviews.reviewText: This grinder has some good points, but not all is good. The removable grinding cup is a big plus, since it can easily be removed for cleaning. It's also quite small, about the size of a plastic drink tumbler. (Note, picture makes it look a lot larger than its actual size.) This small size means it fits nicely on your counter, BUT it has a tiny motor (which clearly labors hard when making fine grinds) and it's capacity is absurdly small. You might think that it can grind a lot more than those tiny pint-size coffee/nut all-purpose grinders (the ones that hold about 30 grains of coffee). In reality, it's NOT much larger. It doesn't help that is has a Max Capacity line that's about halfway up the grinding cup. If you're planning to grind small amounts from time to time, this is a good option. If you're planning to grind lots of coffee, frequently, this is not your machine.

we got this grinder at work and it is a pretty nice grinder. my first and only complaint is with the very short power cord. there is about 3 feet wrapped on the bottom. i didn't see this at first. still is a bit short for me. they address this in the manual saying they did not want a longer cord for fear of a person or pet becoming entangled in or tripping over a longer cord. huh? i make my coffee on the sink counter and i don't run around on it and i would hope pets are a little more coordinated to trip over it too. anyway, 3 grind settings from fine to coarse. selection for number of cups of coffee too. the chamber is easy to open and pour out the ground coffee. twisting the top of the chamber, cleans the coffee grounds from the sides. i really like that option. the ground coffee chamber comes off the grinder for pouring into your machine. all in all a very nice and fun grinder to use!

Since the day I bought this, it takes at least 20 tries before it starts up. The plastic piece that pushes down to connect with starting the motor is not lined up correctly. It is very frustrating to keep pressing the button until it finally connects.

I just submitted the order for my second one. I bought the first grinder about 5 years ago. It's heavily used (2-3 times per week. Sometimes more,) and it held up quite well. The chamber maid cleaning system gave out about 5 minutes ago while I was grinding tomorrow morning's coffee. The motor and blades still work. I suppose I could remove the broken parts and just clean it myself. At any rate, here are some notes:

*The grind is relatively even if you don't overfill it, and correctly guess which setting to use. That takes a bit of practice if you're not going for "12 cup + fine grind" every time.
*I just used water and a scrub brush to clean mine. I didn't want to risk getting any soap residue in my coffee.
*Happily purchased the second unit!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder for the price. CORD IS 26" LONG... REALLY!
reviews.reviewText: I was very pleased with the results of the grind for both my on-stove moka pot and my automated espresso machine, but, like so many others, I was both dismayed and perplexed by the 12" cord. After 10 minutes of fiddling with it, I completely by accident *rotated* the unit while pulling and discovered that what I assumed to be a *retractable* cord ISN"T RETRACTABLE. You MANUALLY UNWIND IT. It finishes unwinding at the point at the back of the unit where the cord notch is. Cord is approx. 26" long. Whew. THAT little bit of info needs to be in the manual!

reviews.reviewTitle: Definitely should've gone w a Krups or something I think
reviews.reviewText: Where to begin with this grinder? The cord is way short, so hope you plan to keep it very close to whatever plug you intend to use. The "settings" for grind is a joke. It's a blade grinder, there isn't a different pulse or something that's going to change your grind. It merely is going to time and shut off based on what you set. If you unplug it, you'll have to redo your settings each time if you decide to use this rather pointless feature. The grinds get stuck to the bottom so that cleaning maid is more a fairy tale. I read some reviews say the arms had worn thin, indicating perhaps plastic being added to your coffee. I haven't noticed that myself and just wanted a blade grinder something inexpensive for the time being. I previously think I've tried Krups, Melita, this thing and a Starbucks one I can't recall the brand for which an old roommate used to have. Of blade grinders for 20 bucks or less, Krups is clearly seeming to be the way to go. Burr grinders are a pain to clean in my overall experience and I don't notice any real difference in the grind despite all the arguments over burr grinding being more squeezing the bean where blades are smashing them around. There is not going to be a noticeable difference that I have found yet in burr vs. blade. Just don't overgrind and burn the oils and be sure to keep things clean and wiped down between bags, especially if you change varieties and you'll be good to go. I gave it two stars because it has been a functional tool for the most part. Some sticking of the button due to design and how grinds can interfere with the switch also. I did like the way the chamber was removable which made for slightly easier cleaning that a one piece. But that's pretty much the only redeeming factor here. Hope this helps you with your purchase, happy shopping!

This coffee grinder, with all its bells and whistles, works only moderately well. Following the directions exactly, it often leaves beans "unground" in the well. I'd prefer a grinder that allows ME to determine how long to grind rather than letting the grinder decide. Yes, I can choose to grind for a shorter amount of time than is pre-programmed, but that's never the issue. The issue is always that the beans need to be ground MORE than the pre-programmed time.

It has been my experience that Mr. Coffee products are overpriced and never live up to expectations. I also found their customer service to be seriously lacking. The last Mr Coffee 4-cup coffee maker I purchased lasted less than a year yet their customer service would do nothing to assist me or help with my disappointment. I bought this grinder because it was on sale; I should have listened to my instinct.

Grinds well enough, BUT.....you have to take it apart and manually move the scrapers around to get all the coffee out once it's ground. It doesn't magically pour out the top the way it's advertised! For that reason I can't give it more than 3 stars and I'm looking for a better grinder. Also the plastic top is now not latching on securely because after a year one of the little latches has partially broken. Not sturdy at all. But if you like fresh ground coffee it's okay.

So far its holding up great n I love the fact its so easy to use than my 5 in 1 system that I always had to get out of cabinet every morning when needed n its a beast . This stays right next to my coffee marker ready to use . Love how its powerful strong for being so tiny . I grind my beans to almost a powder . I like it strong but sweet !

This grinder does not grind uniformly. At first I thought I'd really like it because of the choices of coarse, medium, or fine grind and for how many cups of coffee. I chose 8 for my first grind and put in the appropriate amount of beans and a medium grind. What I found was large pieces of bean on top and extremely fine ground on the bottom. So I tried the second time choosing different combinations. Still the same. Finally I decided to only put in enough beans for 2 cups of coffee and that seemed to work. Since I want to grind more than that at a time and don't want to do it in batches I'm opting for a different grinder.

Then there's the cord issue. I've read that there is 37 in. of cord from another consumer, but I found no way to pull out the short 6 in. of cord that protrudes from the bottom. I found nothing in the directions about more cord, but only an explanation as to why there is such a short cord - in the event a pet gets tangled in it. Really? I've never had a problem with any of my dogs on the counter or even around the house getting tangled in cords! As for me, I prefer not to not have to stand there holding the grinder as it does it's job.

On a bright note, the the housing is nice and creates no mess when used. It has a nice pour feature, and it's easy to clean. This is not enough to make me want to keep it. I'm taking it back and going back to Krups. I had a Krups that lasted for 15 years, ground spices, nuts, and coffee beans. The only reason I didn't get one this time is the local store did not have it on the shelf. I think they should take this on off the shelf. I need an even grind to get the most out of the whole bean. Furthermore, if you DO want to grind spices and nuts it specifically states it is not for that.

After getting home from a camping trip and leaving my trusty grinder in my trailer where it's stored, I realized my fateful mistake too late to turn back so I headed to Walmart to get a new grinder (deciding to leave the old grinder as a camping grinder). I was excited coming across this grinder in the store with the different settings for what specific grind you wanted. However when going to use it getting coffee ready to turn on when I got up in the morning, I was let down. I put in the specified amount of beans for how many cups I intended to make. Selected my grind. And pressed down.... Only to get less than a second of grinding. Hoping it was a fluke I pressed down again only to get no response from the grinder. I even replaced the beans, switched outlets and tried again never to get any sort of grinding from the machine. Not even the one second that it had given before.

I really wanted to like this grinder and hope that I just got a lemon. But I'll be returning the grinder to go with a different grinder and brand. I hope that everyone else has had pleasant experiences as it seems they have but I'll be seeking a new product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Workhorse, sturdy but loud. Shipping was slow.
reviews.reviewText: Grinder works fine. Had one just like it for over ten years and used it nearly everyday, so when it came time to buy another one, I chose the tried and true grinder I was familiar with. Its loud, but Im used to it. And the price is right. Its a workhorse, not a machine for connoisseurs. Shipping was super slow. Im a prime member and this was a prime eligible item and it took two weeks to arrive. Im in Alaska, but thats longer than its supposed to take. Shipping on prime should be 3-7 days. Paid for gift wrapping, but arrived after Christmas. Hindsight...

I actually purchased this at Wmart but saw it on Amazon when shopping for a replacement so thought I'd comment. FYI, my preference is for very fine-ground coffee to get all the flavor I can out of it. What I didn't' like:
- the consistency of the grind: even after a couple rounds of the timed grinding, while most would be ground up, I would still find bigger pieces of bean in the mix (only a few... but still... 45 to 60 seconds of grinding gave me everything from powder to a couple beans left at about peppercorn size.)
-the hinged lid: (why?) Even if I were to pour my ground coffee out of the hinged lid, you need to remove it to spin the plastic scrapers to loosen the finer-ground coffee that gets packed into the grinding chamber. Also the lid has more 'nooks and crannies' than seems necessary (partially due to the hinged feature) making places for grind to stick.
-the plastic scrapers in the grind chamber. functional? somewhat but I still found the need to get my finger to the bottom of the chamber to loosen up the grounds near the blade.
-the timed grinding: just more design than necessary in my opinion. I guess if you are looking for a consistently inconsistent grind, then setting to the cycle of your choice might be a 'nice feature'.

What I DID like: The removable grinding chamber. Made it easy to clean up for the return.

SUMMARY: I think this is an example of a product that is way over-designed for its purpose. Lots of bells and whistles that don't compensate for the less-than-ideal grinding capabilities.

My Krups (203) came yesterday, and this morning was happy to have a simple grinder that does its job well. (And in less than half the grind time!)KRUPS 203-42 Electric Spice and Coffee Grinder with Stainless Steel Blades, Black

I purchased the IDS77 about 9 months ago. It does an adequate job grinding coffee beans. But, about 3 months ago, the plastic "side scrapers" (Chamber Maid Cleaning System) broke off while grinding. Today, I had the machine unplugged and put in a few tablespoons of coffee beans with the top/lid section off. Before putting the lid on, I plugged it into the wall and suddenly the grinder started grinding, sending coffee everywhere in the kitchen until I was able to unplug. I put on the lid, keeping my hand clear of the press/switch and plugged it in again. It started grinding again immediately. There is obviously something wrong with the switch. I cleaned the three-level switch contacts with needles and tried it. It is working correctly, but I'm for sure going to be a lot less trusting that it will work safely.

I use this grinder infrequently. After several months, it's been used about a dozen times. Yesterday, it stopped working. I removed the bean compartment and cleaned it thoroughly, made sure the blades were not jammed or obstructed, replaced the top module and made sure it snapped into position, I then put in the usual 3 scoops of beans, plugged it in, set both controls appropriately and pressed the switch. Nothing. The control lights are on, it's not overfilled but no response. I tried to get help from Mr. Coffee online support but after spending 20 minutes to fill out a detailed form, the submit button did not work. The toll-free phone number was not much better. Very disappointed.

I bought this grinder recently after I pulled my french press out of storage when my drip machine quit on me. This was the least expensive model at Target that had the option to do a coarse grind. Keep in mind, I have never owned a coffee grinder before so I can't compare it to others. I can say that I am happy with my purchase. I like that you can change the settings for the number of cups and Med/fine/coarse ground and the machine automatically shuts off. This took the guess work out of how long to grind for me having never used a coffee grinder.

I have noticed that the grinder doesn't grind the beans very consistently. When I choose coarse ground, there are noticeably larger pieces overall than the med setting but there is quite a lot of more finely ground coffee that remains in the bottom of my cup of coffee. I assume that is to be expected with this type of grinder. I still really like the freshly ground coffee from the french press - beats my automatic machine.

I considered giving this 3 stars for the short cord until I read other reviews about the additional hidden length of cord (thanks, Amazon!). I really like this grinder for the price. Someday I may spring for a more expensive machine but I will keep this one for spices or something.

I've had this for 3 years, I got it from a local store when my simple Braun grinder overheated (don't grind a pound of beans at once!). It still works, which is good, but it's annoying for these reasons:

1. Compared to most push button grinders (like the Krups 203, Bodum Bistro, or Braun that I had), this one has 3 pieces and not just 2: lid, container, body. There's no point in having a separate lid, it's just one more thing to have to dirty. Separating the lid from the container gets grinds everywhere.
2. Chambermaid cleaning system is pointless. It's just more moving parts, more to have to deal with. It also means you have to perfectly align the lid with the container, and the container with the body. Compare this to those other grinders where you can just put the container back on the body with your eyes closed.
3. The timer is garbage. Small quantities end up overground regardless of setting. This isn't a burr grinder, but still... you're better off just figuring out how long you should grind your beans for and sticking with that (I roughly count seconds in my head). I use a french press, so grind size is important. It's also why I finally replaced this with a Capresso Burr grinder (at almost 4x the cost).

If you want a simple grinder, get one of the two I mentioned.

I have disliked other grinders because they trap so much of the ground coffee and they make a mess when trying to empty and clean. I bought this grinder primarily because it had a pouring spout and a cleaning device for the sides of the chamber. This was worse for emptying and cleaning than any other because the pouring spout and side-cleaning device trapped even more grounds than others. I could only think that the designers had deliberately done this to sabotage the brand! How is it possible that the company allowed this to get on the market without testing? Eventually, I learned to NOT use the pouring spot for emptying grounds -so it no longer traps them. The biggest improvement came after REMOVING the cleaning device with wire clippers! NOW I really enjoy this grinder because it grinds to my satisfaction, detaches from the motor portion, empties easily, cleans and even washes easily.

reviews.reviewTitle: Year after year, it keeps on grinding...
reviews.reviewText:
I have an older model that's probably 10 years old and it's still working just like new. Also, bought a new one recently since I started using my old one at work. Seems about the same.

For a blade grinder it just seems like it can't get much better than this. It's very practical - easy to use and clean. Whatever pitfalls it has are common to all blade grinders - it's not uncommon to find larger bean chunks mixed in with the medium grounds and a bit of finer dust. Consistency may be my biggest complaint - it just seems like it can be hard to reproduce the perfect cup once you think you've got it down. I got a cheap kitchen scale to weigh out the beans, which I think is helping.

Now that I'm buying more premium single origin coffees I'm wondering if I should get a burr grinder, but it just seems overly complicated and expensive. Sure, I could get a less expensive manual burr grinder, but then I'll spend 3 minutes doing what this grinder can do in 15 seconds... If I do get a burr grinder I will do a head-to-head blind testing and let you know if there's a difference.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great tool for grinding coffee and saving some cash from ...
reviews.reviewText: Great tool for grinding coffee and saving some cash from buying pre-ground coffee. It even has a little scale on the side to tell you how many TBSP of beans per cup. Only down side is some grounds get stuck on the inside of the grinder, making cleanup a bit more difficult. All in all it is a great product.

Save your money. Recently purchased this grinder after a friend returned from Hawaii with a gift of five pounds of Kona coffee beans. Since purchase I've used the grinder five times, I purchased a hand grinder because the power cord with the Mr. Coffee grinder is only six inches long which made it very difficult to use.

Well today was the fifth time to use the Mr. Coffee grinder and the motor no longer works. The indicator lights work, but not the motor. Save your money!

Purchased this at a brick and mortar store. Apparently missing a part because no lid pressing in the world turns on the motor. (Yes, everything is locked into place.) Tape on box was broken so either the store put a return back on the shelf, or it's China's outstanding production quality control. Guess I'll stick with my old one until it dies.

I have owned many Mr. Coffee products, but buying this coffee grinder was a big mistake. After using it for two months, I am frustrated every time. The coffee grinds well, but the process is needlessly cumbersome. The grinder breaks into three parts, a must-do to get the ground coffee out. Getting "most" of the coffee out of the grinder takes at least 5 minutes. Fortunately I have a Krups ginder brush that I use to "clean" the Mr. Coffee grinder. Mr. Coffee did not include a brush.
