The way the grinding cup works is also a huge plus for us. My husband is partially disabled and has limited mobility and tremors in his left hand. The grinding cup it's lid are easy to put on the grinder unit and take off for him. I had our original grinder (not the Mr. Coffee) in the cupboard as a back up in an emergency. When our previous Mr. Coffee Grinder broke and I was forced to use the old one I HATED IT! The old one did not have the removal grind cup and while trying to pour the grounds from the old grinder into the filter I dropped the entire heavy unit into the coffee maker as the old grinder did not have a removal cup. My husband did the same thing the next day. This grinder is well worth every penny and it is one of the lesser expensive ones.

reviews.reviewTitle: Basic grinder; Defective motor - in less than 5 months
reviews.reviewText: For the price, it did the job of a basic coffee grinder - but for about 5 months before it just stopped functioning. The motor stopped and switch defective. If you buy it, you should go for the protection plan which i regret now. I have been using Mr. Coffee for many years and this product is a bit of an outlier I think.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice that it hasnt been redesigned for years.
reviews.reviewText:
Really good products get redesigned for no good reasons. If its a winner, stick with it.

Like it as well as the last one, which I left too near a hot burner. It worked consistently for many years. Im glad to find the same model.

Nice finish. Cleaning is easy because the container comes off the base. The old grinding compartment, which survived the heat wave, fits perfectly, so I have two.

I was sorry the chambermaid strips didnt last on my first one. They get narrow near the base,and wore through within a year, I think it was. The new ones are a little stiff to work well, and I dont remember the other ones being that way, so maybe theyll loosen up and then be more durable.

The compartment and lid are still a bit of a hassle to fit together, but they loosen up with more use.

I had a Krups before, but it also fell to a heatwave. It worked equally well and had a sleek design and nice finish. It definitely beats Mr. Coffee in style and looks (and price) but having to take the whole thing, cord and all, to the sink everyday to clean it was a deal breaker. Oh, and having to turn it upside to get the coffee into the lid before removing it and inevitably spreading coffee dust that had to be wiped upanother deal breaker. Looks and style lost.
Broke after the first use. Didnt even grind the coffee before it broke.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is the second one of these that I purchased ...
reviews.reviewText: This is the second one of these that I purchased and this one broke within a few weeks. :(

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy, Cost Effective Method for Good Coffee
reviews.reviewText: I bought this as a replacement for a similar Mr. Coffee grinder that I have had for more than ten years. That one still works, but the plastic arms that sweep grounds from the sides have broken in a couple of places, and the motor sometimes sounds a little rough. It had almost daily use for years, and has lasted very well, so I bought this same model as a replacement. I am glad I made the same choice. It works great. Grounds are swept from the sides as beans are ground, and the coffee tastes great when brewing with my drip coffee maker. So what do I like? 1) Great tasting coffee from a cost effective grinder, 2) rotating arms that clean grounds from side of container, and 3) automatic settings for number of cups and type of grind - coarse, medium, and fine, and durability. As already mentioned, the motor on my old grinder of the same model is still going strong, though probably the blades may have dulled a bit, and some cleaning out of the older container is required, due to sweeping arms broken in a couple of places (due to overfilling years ago; my fault). The motor on the older one was beginning to sound a little louder lately as well, which I can hardly complain about considering its age. It still proved to me that this Mr. Coffee grinder is the best choice for grinders in this price range.

So my manual coffee maker broke two days ago leaving me defenseless without my fresh grind in the morning before work so I decided to finally invest in an electric coffee grinder. Needless to say I went with Mr Coffees brand of grinder since Ive been using their 4cup maker for about less than a year I believe and I absolutely love it so far. This arrived this morning so when I got home from work, Immediately washed it, allowed it to air dry with a little wipe around with a paper towel and proceeded to grind about 3tbps of coffee. The coffee grinder grinds more evenly than my manual ever did and plus its programmed to grind for the amount of secs corresponding to the amount of coffee you added and indicated on the device. Not only was my coffee evenly ground in seconds, the brew was a lot smoother than its ever been for the past few months Ive had the manual one. This grinder is easy to clean and assemble. Its small enough that if I left it in my counter I wouldnt be bothered by it, or I could store it in the cabinet. I recommend maybe a fait to weekly clean depending if you prefer to pre grind weekly or daily.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not as cool and helpful as I thought it was going to be...
reviews.reviewText: The redeeming quality of this is that you can remove the bean grinder section for somewhat easy cleaning without worrying about getting the machine itself wet. The settings for cups and grind only change the amount of time the blades spin. It tends to leave a few beans whole most of the time, but this isn't necessarily a deal breaker. Cleaning the bean container can be a pain because of the "sweeper" blade things that are supposed to get the grinds all out for you. I will give it this, it has been going strong for almost a year now without issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great coffee grinder, small and easy to use
reviews.reviewText: We have been using this to grind coffee beans for our French press, multiple times a week for almost a year. It's super easy to use and you can adjust the coarseness of the grind easily. The cup pops right out so you can pour the grinds into your French press or other container. The auto-stop is a nice feature. I would not try and use it for anything else like spices at this point, since I wouldn't want any tiny particles of anything to contaminate the flavor of something else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not give you a consistent grind of beans
reviews.reviewText:
I am not a hard to please customer- If the product does its job as it's supposed to, and the quality complements the price I paid, I am a happy customer. I was debating so long whether or not I should get this based on all the reviews and just decided to take the plunge b/c honestly, I liked the price point and wanted a coffee bean grinder.

This does not give you a consistent grind of beans. I am always left with whole beans within the mix or chunks. If I end up grinding the beans longer, I obviously get a finer grind (which I don't want), but still, there are chunks/coarser pieces within the mix. I've tried giving it a shake while it grinds as well as adding less beans - which all do not work. I am not a snob, and at the end of the day, it's fine that I have to make coffee from a batch of inconsistent grounds, but if you care, do not purchase this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just take a cricket bat to the bag of grounds. It'll work better.
reviews.reviewText: I picked up a bag of whole beans by mistake and didn't realize it until I'd got home, thus requiring a coffee grinder. I usually buy ground coffee because frankly, you could make swill using the chopped up soles of Depression-era workboots and my husband would drink it, so why bother with grinding fresh beans every morning? However, needs must and so I bought this object, which is actually more a coffee-grinder shaped paperweight than a functioning device to render beans into a brewable state. This inaccurately named "coffee grinder" didn't even inconvenience the coffee beans, let alone grind them. In fact, I'm pretty sure I heard giggling from the reservoir, so evidently it doesn't grind as much as it tickles the beans. The green lights on the side are pretty, though.

Works great, does its job. Love that you can just set however many cups/tbsp youre trying to grind and all you gotta do is hold down the lid/button and its perfectly auto-timed for grinding that amount to your selected grind whether it be coarse, med., or fine. Only con would be the lid is not my favorite. You have to hold the little tab to keep it flipped open when you try to pour it out, which can be a little awkward, and the little ridges around the inside of the lid catch alot of the finely ground powder so to aid this i just end up removing the cup and tapping it on the counter to free and then removing the lid and pouring without it. Not worthy of losing a star for that though. Still definitely worth the $. Would totally recommend.

I'm on my third unit now. 1st one lasted 8 years until the motor bearings gave out. 2nd only lasted 2 years until the motor would not turn on That's why 4 stars, not 5. Blade grinders heat the beans (degrades taste) so I keep my beans in a sealed container in the freezer. I fill the bin all the way and shake and turn upside down and sideways to get and even fine grind for Melita filter one cup. I do this twice making enough grounds for a week or so - also keeping the ground coffee in a sealed container in the freezer. Using high quality beans (Peet's) I am very satisfied with taste and aroma.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good, but be aware that it isn't an Auto-grind, must hold grind button
reviews.reviewText:
first of all, this grinder does not perform a timed grind with the push of a button. Looking at the fact that I could choose grind type and amount, I assumed that I would hit start and it would do the grind for me. this is helpful for when I have a headache and don't want to stand next to a loud coffee grinder while it grinds. But this one simply "times" it for you so you know when to stop manually pressing the grind button.
Also, the pour function seems neat but it actually is less easy to pour all grounds out then a regular cheap grinder.
That said, I like that it lets you know how long to grind, and it's my fault for assuming it was an auto-grind, and I like that it has a choice of grinds, it seems to make good grounds, and it looks nice.

This grinder works ok, and has features that look useful but I don't think that they are. I know blade grinders don't have quite the same consistency as burr grinders. but this one is way off the mark I think that the ribs that move to dislodge the fine coffee buildup and make for easier use, actually prevent the grind from being consistent. Instead of having a smooth bowl to create the nice coffee bean "whirlpool" effect, the inside plastic pieces prevent the beans from being ground. I do like the timer, so you can make sure that the grind time is the same each time. The unit comes apart into three pieces and is a little cumbersome. We use it every day and the motor seems fine. Our last grinder had a timer and would stay running without having to hold the lid down. I really liked that feature.

reviews.reviewTitle: And it still does not disappoint! With settings for size of grinding sample and ...
reviews.reviewText: Outstanding and well-made product. I had a previous version of this tried and tested model from 6 or 7 years back, but had actually stopped drinking coffee for a year or so. When I started back to my morning coffee, I couldn't find this little beauty so I found it on Amazon and reordered it. And it still does not disappoint! With settings for size of grinding sample and separate grinding textures, it's still hands down one of the best grinders on the market and still affordable! I am now using a French Press, so used the "coarse" setting for the first time - absolutely perfect results, exquisite coffee from expensive Costa Rican beans. This rugged, versatile little machine is back on the counter being used daily and delivers great results every time. The manufacturer hasn't changed it at all in nearly a decade and that's all you need to know, really. It just works great every time and there's a reason it's still one of the best sellers after all this time. It works well and is affordable. Just buy it. ??

I purchased this grinder because the top is removable and I thought that it would make less of a mess. It actually makes more of a mess. While grinding don't left your finger off quickly while the blades are spinning. The lid is light weight so it needs pressure to hold it down. If you're in a hurry and you forget, a little bit of coffe powder will puff out of the sides of the lid. I was also disappointed in the inconsistency of the grind compared to my last grinder that was cheaper than this one. When trying to poor out the coffee the container is difficult to use without spilling a little. The container has parts in it that get coffee stuck to it so I have to fidget with it to get most of the coffee out.

My prior Mr. Coffee grinders both failed almost immediately; they had some kind of slide-forward mechanism that lasted 3 or 4 uses. This one has been hanging in for a couple of months. My backup is an antique hand grinder, but sometimes speed is of the essence. And when my daughter sends me Street Bean Coffee fresh roasted in Seattle (Belltown blend) that's an emergency! Coffee time no matter what time of day it arrives. Am sipping some now, and thought it high time I review the grinder. Mr. Coffee finally got it right.

I thought I had reviewed this previously.
Anyway, this is the 3rd one of these I bought in the past 15 or so years. Each time, it was the plastic "sweeper" that broke, not the mechanism.
It grinds pretty consistently, but can leave some unbroken beans. If I am using an expensive bean, I use a strainer to sift my grind. Then I put the unground beans back in and grind them up.
Not very loud. Easy to clean, and static not really an issue. The inside sweeper that gets the grinds off the sides of the machine is EXCELLENT.
It does what it does very well for a long time without a lot of thought. I recommend.

After trying several subpar pepper grinders and realizing my mortar and pestle has limits on what I can turn into powder, I found this item.

Inexpensive, easy to use, small footprint on counter or in cabinet. Turns peppercorns into coarse or fine grind in seconds. Easily turned a cinnamon stick, cardamom seeds and cloves into garam masala powder.

This product is easy to take apart and clean. I'm happy with it and would buy again.

Ok, so I blew up my other grinder....or I should say HIGH SPEED SLICER. So I bought another one with good reviews...this one and I can that this is a HIGH SPEED SLICER. There is not consistancy. If you are a French Press person Go for it. But if you like consistent grounds. Don't buy this thing. Spend 20 bux more and by a burr grinder. This thing is ok for super fine or Course tho the course isn't consistent at all... So I give this a Mehhhh.. its cheap and chops the beans and if that is all you care about then Go for it

reviews.reviewTitle: Within minutes your beans are ground
reviews.reviewText: This is a powerful little machine. Forget the K-cups. Sometimes you just need to slow down and enjoy a delicious old fashion flavorful cup of coffee. After choosing from a variety of beans that you could purchase on amazon. Just add some beans and within no time your beans will be grounded and ready for brewing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very good grinder for the money
reviews.reviewText:
This is the second Mr. Coffee grinder I purchased. I liked the 1st one so much I ordered the 2nd for the RV. We used expensive burr grinders in the past that were more trouble than they were worth. Besides, they were too big and if you want a good cup of coffee you should grind right before each pot so what's the point of a large one?
This is easy to use. It is somewhat noisy but so what. Just don't grind anything while anyone is sleeping. Oh....what ever you do, DON'T pull on the cord thinking it will retract. It's not like that. It unwinds. If you look closely you can see the groove underneath where the cord is tucked in. Just unwind it until it's long enough. I went crazy trying to figure it out with the first time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beans are not completely ground no matter how long you grind them!
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to like this new grinder but there are a couple of things about it I don't like. There are too many parts and too many twists and turns to operate it. Most frustrating part is that there is an adjustment for size of grind and also you are supposed to let the grinder know how many beans you are asking it to grind! I prefer my old Krups grinder. Easy to dump the beans in, evenly ground and easy to scoop/pour the ground coffee out. This one is difficult to scoop the ground coffee out and well as A LOT of ground coffee sticks to the bottom of the grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works fine for the price. Would buy again.
reviews.reviewText: Like this, but it's not as easy to clean or dispense as other reviews let on. I really like that it automatically shuts off if you set the grinder to your preferred consistency. No more guessing! Note, however, the grinder itself does not "shut down"...you still need to unplug it. The "spout", though, just doesn't do much to make pouring the grounds out any easier than my last grinder without one. The plastic "scrapers/spatulas" inside do scrape the grounds off the side, but their presence then makes it difficult to clean without putting it in the dishwasher...which I don't run every day because I don't always have a full load of dishes.

The plastic "chamber maid" side-wipers broke on my old one, after years of almost-daily use. This new one appears to be identical and I hope that it will also give years of service and grind countless thousands of beans.
I use the "course" setting for peculator coffee and the fine setting for espresso. For espresso, I set it to "fine" and run it more than once to get it extra fine.
A fussy coffee snob might find fault in this device, but it is great for the rest of us.

Im not totally impressed with this grinder. Theres a decent amount that gets stuck to the bottom of the inside on the "coarse" and "fine" settings. Its not that big of a deal, just annoying to have to smack it around a little to get it clear and then rinse it out every time to make sure it doesn't get clogged up. Its also super loud, so I have to make sure I remember to use it before the kids go to bed, as im usually making a cup around 10pm before I leave for graveyard shift. In the end, it gets the job done. Its also a bit hilarious reading reviews of people complaining about the cord being too short, not realizing it wraps around on the inside for more convenient storage...

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible and lasted only exactly 4 months.
reviews.reviewText: Almost exactly 4 months into purchasing this from Amazon the grinder will not grind anymore. It's a mechanical failure as even though the lights show power the grinder will not activate. Amazon's return window on this is only 30 days, so now I'm completely out of a grinder and my money. Ugh!!! What a disaster.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fine for perk, but not espresso
reviews.reviewText: I like some of the features....it has an easy open lid and isn't too loud. It comes apart if I need it to. Seems easy to clean. The settings for the grind don't seem to make a difference. Even on the "fine" setting there are plenty of inconsistent large chunks that don't seem to get ground. I even shake the crap out of it. Luckily for me I don't mind a medium grind, but if you need a fine grind for espresso this won't work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought this grinder twice because it works so well
reviews.reviewText: The first time I bought this product, I used it daily for several years before it burned out. I bought another one because even though it burned out after ~3-4 years, it still worked amazingly and for a long time, given the inexpensive price. It's also easy to clean.

I LOVE this little thing. No matter what they say about which type of coffee grinder is better, this little thing is perfect. Not too noisy, easy to handle. Doesn't exactly "pour" very well - kind of a clumsy pour. But I just scoop the grounds out - no need to pour them, really. As for the grinder being perfect - I'm known as a coffee snob. No grocery store coffee beans for me. I own several types of grinders, from the type that sound like an Indy car to the high pitched whirring. Burr, blade - I've got them all. And coffee makers from espresso machine, to BUNN, to french press to pour over. I'm sticking with this grinder.

I've used this for a while and am happy with it. Two small pushbuttons select the amount of beans to grind and the fineness of the result you want, and then you push down on the lid until the grinding stops. So long as the unit is plugged in, it retains its settings. That's very handy for me because I make about the same amount of coffee each morning.

The two-part top unit (grinding chamber and lid) lifts out easily with a twist. Turning the lid assembly back and forth on the grinding chamber makes three plastic vanes wipe across the inner walls of the chamber so that no coffee sticks there when you empty the coffee into your brewer. Both parts can be machine-washed, a real plus -- especially if you (like me) grind other stuff like hot peppers.

The is not a real "grinder" of course, merely a chopper, so the consistency of the grounds isn't the best; but it seems pretty good.

HOWEVER -- the power cord is ridiculously short. It won't even reach the AC socket directly behind and above my grinder. I have to put the grinder on a box. What were they thinking???

Five stars at this price, less one for the power cord.

April 2016: STILL grinding. Everything still works. We grind about 15 cups worth a day, and it shows no sign of slowing down. In this day when everything seems to come with planned obsolescence, this little thing is well made.

October 2013: Returning this to 5 stars. This little thing just keeps chugging. I am so happy with it. Losing the little Chamber Maid Cleaning System was really not a big thing other than a momentary disappointment. But in a world of planned obsolescence, this grinder keeps working like a charm. I love the many stage variable grind it allows because I can use it to grind coffee for French press, pour overs, brewed, and espresso. And we still find that we use substantially less coffee to achieve our preferred flavor than with other grinders.

April 2011: After 6 months, I had to downgrade my rating because the little Chamber Maid cleaning system crumbled one morning as we ground our coffee. Just broke into several pieces, leaving us with a great grinder, but now without a way to easily clean out the last of the coffee which tends to remain in the grinder and get stale. I realize that for $14.95, I could just purchase another one, but I would have expected it to have lasted at least one year. Planned obsolescence irritates me. Leaving my original review below, because I was thrilled with it until that six month point.

October 2010: Read Joseph Marsh's 4 star review of this product to get the whole scoop, but I just had to put my 2 cents worth in. I gave it 5 stars because I'm absolutely ecstatic with it. I've had a small, simple Krups grinder for years, but we wanted something with a larger chamber to grind at least 12 cups at a time. I looked at other brand names, ignoring the "Mr. Coffee" for a while thinking I wanted something more sophisticated. ::shakes head:: But I was not happy with the reviews and the prices of "more sophisticated" grinders.

With my little Krups, I was doing a count-the-seconds:shake:count-the-seconds:shake:count-the-seconds routine to get just the right grind. This Mr. Coffee grinder takes all the guess work out of it, and I found we were even using LESS coffee per full pot because of the perfect grind.

I also love the Chamber Maid Cleaning System -- so simple, yet so worth it rather than having to dig out the fine grind with my scoop handle every time as I did with the Krups.

The removable chamber is great, too. Just neater and handier than having to unplug and drag the whole grinder over to scoop out the coffee.

Best and most fun product I've bought in a long time!!! (Oh, and we're still using the Krups for grinding nuts and spices for which it actually seems better suited.)

This kind of cheap coffee grinder will get the job done if you don't care at all about uniformity of the grind. Set to its most coarse setting, it chips away at the beans creating a mixture of barely cracked beans and super fine powder. For my purposes (cold brew with coarse grind) this device was a total waste of money. I ended up just putting the beans in a ziplock bag and smashing them with a rolling pin.

reviews.reviewTitle: Two year review: Still running, cleaning a hassle, but worth the price
reviews.reviewText:
Two year review: The grinder is still operational with regular use (about 3 times a month). It grinds really well and does varying degrees of coarseness. The build is still solid despite being plastic. The cord is long enough to use at least 3 feet away from an outlet.

The biggest downside so far in the past 2 years: Cleaning can be a pain, but needed at least every time you grind. But despite diligently washing the container where the beans go, the inside edge start to accumulate bits of coffee grinds. It's annoying, but it hasn't lowered the quality of the coffee grounds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Value, Easy to use, Gets the Job Done!
reviews.reviewText: I have only had this for a few days, so I will update if necessary if I have any issues with it. This is an attractive and functional unit. Grinds coffee in no time at all. (I previously used a crank burr grinder with a French press). When my burr grinder broke, I replaced it with this. It is less expensive, but I haven't noticed a difference in the quality of flavor in my coffee and this is much easier to use and faster. I'm very happy with this purchase and the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wanted to love it just could not
reviews.reviewText: It does grind as advertised, that being said it over grinds no matter what setting you choose leaving a fine grit in your coffee regardless of filter type. Pulverizes more than a grind tried three different brewing methods with three different styles (drip, press, as well as pour over chemex) also tried each setting and the process didnt inmprove quality in any way.

I have one of these grinders bought a few years ago and it still works well. Much better, in fact, than the new version. The cord on this version is much shorter and I don't understand the reason for that. The manufacturer seems to think a person is going to trip over it, but who is ever walking on their kitchen counter, for Pete's sake! It also doesn't grind the beans as uniformly as the old grinder. Please go back to the older design that works so much better all the way around!

We got this to replace our grinder. We previously had the same model and it lasted us years and did an incredible job. This one is awful.
It doesnt grind the coffee well, even though we keep it below the maximum fill line. We have to shake the coffee to adjust it, and regrind. Otherwise it only gives us a coarse grind, despite being set to fine. And again, we had the exact same mode previously, so we know how to set it and use it.
We threw out the box because we knew we loved it since we had previously owned it. Huge mistake. If I still had the box I would have returned and and bought something that actually worked.
Total disappointment.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works decently, way too loud though
reviews.reviewText: This is the first coffee grinder I've owned, and I think it works decently well as far as coffee grinders go. It does take me two tries to get everything ground up evenly though, and it is so loud that I have to hold it in my hands off the counter because if I use it on the countertop it sounds like a train is coming through my apartment. Even holding it it's still really loud and high pitched and abrasive, and sometimes I smell a hot plastic smell like it can barely handle grinding coffee even just once a day, so I don't think it'll last me too long. Good for the price considering the different settings it has, but I wouldn't get it again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works, but I'd been just as happy with a cheaper one
reviews.reviewText: Not that impressed with this item. It has different selections on the side to change amount of coffee to be grinded and fineness of grind, but the only thing I can tell it changes is the position of the light (2,4, course, fine, etc.) The chamber cleaning doesn't work very well. All in all, it works, but I was just as happy with my old one that finally died that I paid $7 for.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm not buying pre-ground coffee anymore....
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this grinder for about a month, and I'm impressed. The last time I ground my own coffee was about ten years ago. I had a blade-type grinder back then too, but it was the old design design, where only the lid came off. The blades and grinding-chamber were built into the motorized base. It was necessary to flip the thing upside-down to get the grounds into the lid/cup. Then, when I'd separate the lid from the base, some portion of grounds would always escape onto the counter. It was so messy and difficult to clean that it wasn't worth grinding my own coffee. This new design seems to work quite well. I have yet to make a mess with the coffee grounds. After grinding the beans, I twist the chamber to remove it from the motorized base. I flip up the lid and pour the grounds into my coffee maker. There is even a built-in component that sweeps the edges of the chamber to dislodge the grounds so I don't have to bang on it to get them out. To activate the sweep, I simply twist the container while pouring the grounds into my coffee maker. After all this, I twist the lid to remove it from the container and tap everything on the edge of my sink to release any lose remnants. All the pieces are clearly marked to make reassembly easy. I put the pieces back together and the grinder sits on my counter all nice & clean.

Consistent grounds -
The new design also makes it easy to have a good, consistent grind. The old model had an on/off mechanism - that was it. I never really knew how long to let the thing run. What if I were making 6-cups instead of 12-cups? What if I wanted strong coffee instead of weak coffee? What if I ground the beans too long and made coffee bean dust that clogged my filter and overflowed coffee-soup onto my counter? This new design solves the problem. With a push of a couple of buttons, I can specify how many cups of coffee I'm planning for and whether I want it weak or bold. I haven't compared the grind consistency to that of a burr grinder, but this little thing seems to do a fine job. My understanding is that burr-type grinders provide the best consistency of grounds, but they're more expensive and difficult to clean. I paid $20 for this little guy and it's easy to use and clean.

Cleaning -
The instructions say the grinding container and lid can be hand-washed or placed on the top rack of the dishwasher. I recommend hand-washing because I had a poor experience with the dishwasher. The container has an inner stainless-steel cup where the beans are ground. Outside of this cup is a clear-plastic housing. When the dishwasher removes food particles from the other dishes, some of the particles become lodged between these two grinder components. To get the food residue out of my grinder container I had to completely disassemble it - rinsing wouldn't get them out. On a positive note, I can say that the grinder container was easily disassembled and reassembled with a #1 Phillips screwdriver. It also gave me an opportunity to evaluate the engineering, manufacturing and assembly of this particular part of the grinder. Overall, I think this grinder is a very good deal for $20.

Only complaint -
If there were one thing I would improve, it would be the on/off switch. The manufacturing and assembly tolerances are pretty good for a $20 grinder. However, a slight difference in tolerances can make a person have to push really hard on the switch to turn on the grinder. In my opinion, the design should have added millimeter on the plunger that activates the switch.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor Quality. Stopped working after 5 grinds.
reviews.reviewText:
I used the grinder as instructed and it stopped working after only 5 grinds. Hopefully Mr. Coffee will refund my money as its a week outside of the return period.

Update. I reached out to Sunbeam ( the maker of Mr Coffee products) today. The call was quick ( I was not put on hold for a long time) and the customer service rep was very pleasant. She said I should receive a replacement in 7-10 days. I also asked if instead of getting this model ( with more bells and whistles than I need) could she send me out a simpler ( less prone to failure) model and she said sure. While I can't recommend this coffee grinder, I commend Sunbeam/Mr. coffee for excellent customer service!

reviews.reviewTitle: Died faster than a Kardashian marriage
reviews.reviewText: Overheated and expired the first time I used it. Another bad product from China.

reviews.reviewTitle: So Basic. Yet So Good, Durable And Reliable.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this grinder since March of 2010 and I've used every single day since. I'm not a coffee "connoisseur" by any means. My needs are basic, I want a good cup of coffee made from fresh ground beans, and this coffe grinder does the job every single time without any issues.

Like I said, I've had it for over 2 years now and it has done a great job; the blades are still sharp and the overall state of the grinder is pretty much intact. I grind my coffee every morning, 8 cups (7-8 spoons), medium setting. Perfect. Coffee comes out perfectly ground and ready for my drip style coffee maker. You can grind in three stages, coarse, medium and fine; plus up to 12 cups of coffee, each time and each setting has an automatic timer, so you simply press the on button, keep it pressed, the grinder stops automatically.

I like the fact that the chamber comes apart and can be thoroughly cleaned by hand or in the dish washer, so after a week or so, or when switching to a different type of coffee, I can easily clean and avoid any left overs in the cup.

Some here have complained about the noise, and it is noisy, but not to the extend of what some have said. So, if you are a regulare guy/gal, looking for a decent, fresh cup of coffee and don't want to spend a load of money for some fancy grinder that pretty much does the most basic thing..grind coffee... then look no further, this unit is low priced, works great and lasts. Hope this helps.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Handsome Design That Does a Mediocre Grinding Job
reviews.reviewText: This is a good news/bad news product. The good news is: It a neat, handsome design and you can immerse the removable grinding cup and top for cleaning. The bad news is: it does a mediocre job of grinding (very many large pieces remain after grinding) and their ballyhooed internal cup-cleaning wipers do nothing useful. I previously used a Krups F203 grinder which did a better grinding job but could not be immersed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for grinding up just about anything, seeds, softer nuts, dry dog food, you name it, weve done it!
reviews.reviewText:
This is a very good and durable (so far) grinder.
I am giving a review having used this item for a somewhat different purpose than what it was made for though.
Use it to grind dry dog food into a powder to mix into fresh foods for a dog with teeth problems, works amazingly well for that.
Also have used it to grind peanuts into coarse powder/meal form, for mixing into smoothies etc.
Have had no problems, use it several times a day now for a few weeks.
Still very sharp, easily cleaned, have no complaints.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds Coffee, makes peanut butter too
reviews.reviewText:
Although I have a graveyard of electric coffee grinders used for coffee, spices, or coffee and spices, I have yet to come across a grinder with the flexibility of this little monster.

For an inexpensive chamber grinder, this grinder does the job quite well. It works great for your coffee, period. Fine through coarse grinds it does competently. I am not 100% sure what the effects of the cups and coarseness buttons are, but the transparent chamber allows you to keep an eye on the grind with ease and the blades deliver a generally uniform grind (as long as you don't overfill).

Cleaning the unit is easy despite the plastic arms inside; quickly washing and wiping clean, the unit dries quickly. The "Chamber Maid" arms are a bit unnecessary, but can be semi-effective at releasing some of the ground beans from the walls and foot of the chamber. You could also do this with your finger and break out the arms (some friends of mine with the same grinder have done this and it has not impacted performance).

Typically, you are instructed to keep separate grinders for spices and coffee beans. For someone who regularly grinds all manner of chili and curry powders, the materials used to make the grinder have yet to impart any of those flavors to the beans (assuming a quick cleaning).

And by chili powder, I don't just mean grinding allspice berries, but also taking toasted then soaked peppers and pureeing them. Speaking of pureeing, I have made both cashew and peanut cheese (using soaked nuts) in this coffee grinder. Can't afford a vita-mix? No problem.

I've had the same coffee grinder for years. It won't stop working, but it's also kind of difficult to deal with. So, I got this one and it has all the features I need. Made with the consumer in mind. So many settings. Easy to fill, take coffee out and to clean. It grinds nicely for my press and for my espresso maker. Hope this one lasts as long as my other one has... which is forever. Ha!

reviews.reviewTitle: Ground the coffee beans pretty well, but the spindle inside doesn't reach all ...
reviews.reviewText: Ground the coffee beans pretty well, but the spindle inside doesn't reach all the way to the bottom. As a result, I have to hand scoop the ground coffee out of the bottom. I also would prefer a grinder that produces finer grinds for my espresso machine. This is my first coffee grinder, so I may be biased. Overall, it was a great product for the price.

I'm so thankful I discovered this product. I usually grind up a week's worth of my favorite coffee during the weekend to enjoy during the week.
When setting it up, be sure to read the instructions. The grind/cup size setting is a bit confusing if it's your first time using the machine. But overall, it's easy and simple to operate.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the Job But Could Be Better
reviews.reviewText: I've had a manual grinder for many years but decided I needed to replace it with a more automated one. This grinder works well and is a step up from my old grinder, but it does have a few minor issues. The ground coffee is not totally removed by twisting the cap. On the plus side, the cup can be detached and washed without exposing electric components to water. I learned not to overfill the cup with beans. Doing so means an incomplete grind. The grinder does stop when done and seems to do a good job in grinding the beans to the desired fineness setting. The unit defaults to medium settings when unplugged, which I was not aware of until I noticed it later. It's not perfect but I'm happy with it for the price I paid.

reviews.reviewTitle: Buy it for looks. Functionality has a couple of design flaws.
reviews.reviewText: Very cool, sleek design! Looks great on the countertop. I like that you can set how fine and how strong you want the beans ground. Just choose the settings you want, put the coffee beans in, and push the top down until it stops. I think I would use a cheaper, different grinder for grinding spices since they are ground fine and it is difficult to get fine ground things out of this product without spilling quite a bit of it. The coffee gets stuck on three inner seams and the blades, especially when fine ground. Between the seams and the blades, it is difficult to get a spoon or scoop or anything in there to dislodge the stuck-on coffee. Also, it is difficult to keep the top up/open when putting in the beans or taking out the coffee. It keeps falling back down. It grinds the coffee pretty well if you hold the lid down until it stops grinding. Yes, YOU have to hold the lid down to make it grind, but it only takes a few seconds.

I was looking forward to getting this because my old burr grinder just wasn't doing the job anymore. I specifically got this because it's a space saver (just about to head to college) and it has the "Chamber Maid" system to get all of the grounds out.

Pros: compact, easy to use, chamber maid system, and the grind setting for drip makers is great. I feel like it unlocked more flavors than my old grinder did.

Cons: cord is a hassle to unwind and rewind, pain to wash, and the first time I used it, I noticed after I had brewed my coffee that there were still a few wholes beans in the grounds. Also, though there's a choice for how many cups to make, they want you to measure out the grounds afterwards, which means (if you're a coffee snob like me) if there's any leftover grounds, they'll be thrown away.

Overall, for the price, it's pretty good. My old burr grinder was around $75, so I'm not expecting perfection out of this.

I have read many reviews on this little grinder before purchasing one for myself. I have read the plastic scraper over time wears down. People were even worried about getting cancer from consuming the powdered plastic. Well the coffee grinder works great and fast, plenty of cord wrapped around the bottom, just unwind it. As for the cancer from the plastic, think of all the chemicals being sprayed on the bean itself during it's maturing to keep bugs from eating them. 80% of all coffee comes from 3rd world countries and they spray the heck out of them so who cares if the plastic slowly goes away?

Enjoy your grinder and coffee!

Update as of 02-Feb-12, one year later.

This little grinder is an absolute maniac, I use it all the time and since day one it will rip those helpless coffee beans to pieces perfectly every time. The plastic scraper is showing a little wear but this is not really a problem. If you enjoy fresh ground coffee everyday and don't want to spend hundreds of dollars then buy this one. I know it will never let you down. I really enjoy mine.

Last Update 03/09/2013

Still grinding strong, you have to get one today!

I had a Krups blade grinder for years and it finally broke. I thought I'd try something different so I bought the Mr. Coffee ISD77 with Chamber Maid Cleaning.

OK..I used the grinder 3 times and I've now ordered a new Krups to replace it.

Pros: It looks nice and it appears that it has some neat features

Cons: Poor Design
The "features" don't work right or are just on the "ridiculous side"

Here's what I mean. First the design. The Mr. Coffee is circular in shape. No matter how long you grind, you get some beans that are turned into powder, others that are in chunks...that's because in a circle, there is not the same colliding of particles as in an oval shape or some other shape that simply spins in a circle.

On the Krups Fast Grind, the shape the grinder is an oval. This forces the beans into odd patterns and the grinds are much more uniform.

"Chamber Maid"...it sounds like a good idea. In practice it doesn't work well. Some grounds do in fact fall off of the sides when you move the prongs, but others stay stuck, not to mention those that stick into the top of the grinder.

I thought the lift-off top would be great. But it just turned out to be too many parts. The Krups is two part: Top and bottom with motor. The Mr. Coffee is 3 parts and the advantage is supposed to be that you can subject it to the dishwasher. I'd recommend the Krups and just use a brush to get some of the left over grounds out of it's base.

The Mr. Coffee is going into the garage sale pile.

This electric coffee grinder is PERFECT! I can grind as little or as much coffee as I need. The three grind settings make it so I can have French Press to espresso and many varieties in between.

Clean up is a breeze, so you wont have old grounds fouling your coffee.

I would have given 5 stars, but, there's no good way to store the elecrical cord. Maybe the next version could be rechargeable?

reviews.reviewTitle: A grinder with a 'cleaning system' that actually makes everything dirtier..
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:

- Price

Cons:

The advertised 'cleaning system' makes everything messier. This 'cleaning system' interferes with coffee grinds so it actually takes longer to get the grind you want. I had to run the 'fine' cycle twice to actually get a fine grind. Since the coffee grinds can't move freely around the grinding chamber - they fly everywhere inside and actually wind up getting spread all over the lid and lid/cup edge so when you open the lid, grinds fall all over your counter.

The 'cleaning system' doesn't actually do much and is rather hard to turn if you grind your coffee fine. The grinds get stuck under the plastic ring and it doesn't turn smoothly.

Plain and simple this is a poorly designed product. Yes it grinds coffee but there are other blade grinders that do just as good of a job, that are less messy and can easily be cleaned with a simple wipe of a paper towel in the grinding chamber.

Returned.

Never owned a Coffee Grinder before and many of them are so expensive. This one wasn't at all. The reason for my purchase was we received a Keurig Coffee maker as a Christmas gift and I felt it was too expensive to buy those small cups of coffee and wanted to just use the coffee I like to use right out of a can that I always used in our regular coffee maker. Problem was the coffee grounds right out of the coffee can were too coarse for the Keurig Coffee maker and the hot water runs right through them making a weak cup of coffee so I run the canned coffee once again through my Mr.Coffee Grinder. I then put the newly ground coffee in to a couple of small containers to store the coffee to use in the Keurig Coffee Machine to last for a couple of weeks. The grinder itself is very easy to clean so it isn't really much work at all and I now get a good cup of coffee when I feel I only want a cup or two instead of making a whole pot the old way.

So you put your beans in, tell it how much coffee you are making, and how to grind the beans. Then just hold down the lid and wait for it to stop spinning. I'm by no means a coffee snob, and I don't make espresso, but it works great in my French press and drip coffee maker. I would recommend it. Love that I don't have to guess and check on how course or fine the grind is. It does it for me.

I am extremely pleased with this. The value/price is excellent. I bought it so that I could get a coarse grind for my french coffee press. I cannot afford a conical burr grinder. This handy grinder lets you set the grind as well as the number of cups you intend to make. You have to hold down the button for grinding until it stops based on your settings. I'm impressed with this Mr. Coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: When she was visiting with her husband they really liked the way the coffee tastes and smells when it ...
reviews.reviewText: We have this model and I bought one for my daughter. When she was visiting with her husband they really liked the way the coffee tastes and smells when it is freshly ground. So do I. I like this grinder but when we have company it takes 2 grinds to provide the amount we need to keep every one full of java. So the reservoir is smallish but we like it dark and heavy so the product is fine we are not? I would also recommend based on noise. our previous grinder sounded like a chain saw this one is much quieter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great coffee grinder, is holding up extremely well to constant use.
reviews.reviewText: My husband loves this little coffee grinder. He uses this every morning. It can grind plenty of beans for multiple people or a smaller amount for just one person. My husband has switched completely over to whole bean coffee due to this wonderful grinder. We especially like how the top portion twists off so that you don't have to tip the whole thing to dispense.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best on market for price and grind
reviews.reviewText: I could tell you the top is a little strange getting on or the cord's a little short. But for the price it does everything and more. One thing about more expensive units - the coffee's in a separate cup but you have an awkward blade cleaning situation later; dump that idea of 'convenience'. This grinds and the blade unit/cup detaches - for easy pour, frig, clean; no rinsing the unit with motor intact. The design allows for easy cleaning; you can scrape sides even without a brush The GRIND can be a smooth fine espresso - I've even dusted my chocolate candies it's so nice. .I had another unit and it could grind to 'drip' ; nothing finer. This little one is almost like the big commercial units; which maximizes coffee bean flavor. I grind for 2 days' worth; put the top in the frig. Happy purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does it's job, and does it well
reviews.reviewText:
There are some items that when I buy, I think I can't be impressed with. Not that they don't do their job, but that there is no way to be above average. One of these is a paper coffee filter. It filters to coffee. As long as it doesn't crumble into pieces or have a giant hole in it, I am happy. I used to think a coffee grinder was one of these things. From my perception, I thought a coffee grinder would either work or not work, and there wasn't anything special about one over the other, but Mr. Coffee managed to make a simple product into something extraordinary.

This coffee grinder has three features that are completely revolutionary compared to my older blade grinders:

1) The section with the beans comes off so you can pour it into the pot. This seems like something so obvious. After all, blenders have done this for years. Yet coffee companies consistently make us try and figure out how to make the grounds jump from the grinder to the pot. This one has the top section pull off from the base so you can pour it.

2) The chamber maid system. It really isn't a cleaning system, it is a functional system (And something I would love to see on a blender). Basically you turn the cap back and forth and plastic edges knock all the grounds off the side so that they pour into the pot easily. For anyone that has tried to figure out how to get the coffee from the bottom section on the side by the blade, you know this is a revolutionary change from the norm.

3) The grinding process. With this grinder you set it to how many cups you want and how coarse you want the grounds. Then you add the amount of coffee you said you were going to on the grinder, and hold it down. When it shuts off, the coffee is finished. It comes out even, and it comes out the thickness that I said I wanted. This is great since I own both a coffee maker and an espresso maker that require different levels of coarseness of the grounds.

Overall I love it and the best part is that it is also cheaper than most grinders on the market!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder, not for single use
reviews.reviewText: This is a great grinder with lots of grinding options. The only problem I have is trying to cleanly transfer the coffee grinds from grinder to K-Cup. In order to fill the cup, I have to use a funnel to prevent a mess. I would recommend this grinder for coffee pot users and not for single-serve uses. I realize it advertises for 12 cups, but I was hoping it could accommodate the single use too.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder has already been retired to the back of the shelf.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is difficult to clean and to extract the ground coffee. You have to hold the button to grind the coffee as it does not run on a timer in accordance with the number of cups you select. I find this grinder less convenient than other blade grinders I have tried. I have gone back our old burr grinder which gives a much more consistent grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: A bargain coffee grinder, couldn't ask for more at this price
reviews.reviewText:
Update 10/1/2016
Still using this grinder, still going strong!

Update 1/9/2012 -
I've had this grinder for almost two years now, and still have nothing but good things to say. It still works well, is easy to clean and grinds the coffee consistently. It is very easy to overfill this grinder - the "fill line" mark is only about halfway up the cup, and it is the truth. If you fill it above that level, the beans will not grind evenly. So, follow the directions, clean regularly, and you'll have a dependable coffee bean grinder.

*~*~*~*~

I believe I paid about $15 for this coffee grinder, and it is well worth it. It grinds the beans consistently and finely. The fact that the container that holds the coffee is removable is a really nice feature, along with the blades that you can move back and forth to help scrape the coffee off of the sides without getting your fingers dirty. I find that the setting to grind it fine doesn't run long enough, so I just run it for a few additional seconds and the coffee is ground to perfection for my use, in an Aeropress. I'd recommend this grinder to anyone looking for a bargain blade type grinder, and I'd buy one again.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is the best grinder! So versatile and easy to clean
reviews.reviewText: This is the best grinder! So versatile and easy to clean. Includes a builtin "bowl scraper" or "cleaning maid" to sweep the sides of the bowl after grinding. Multiple settings to get beans ground for up to 12 cups of coffee or as few as 4 cups--perfect! And it does not take up much space--great design.

reviews.reviewTitle: It requires user to hold the power button during the entire timed grind, until it stops.
reviews.reviewText: It's not hard to use, but there are easier models. Three things I don't like about this model (I used it for 18 months). 1) pouring out the ground coffee could be easier. Maybe a spout? 2) There's a timer, but you have to hold the power switch (press the top) for the duration of the grind. 3) It has LED lights that are poi tless and always on.

My coffee-friend fanatic recommended this to me, and I really enjoy it. The two parts that can contact the coffee are both removable, which makes this a pleasure to clean. The only wish-list item I would make is if this could remember the previous settings when I plug it back in: I only grind coffee at home on weekends, and if I forget to readjust the setting then it won't be for the right number of cups and for the right coarseness.

It's a very sturdy grinder with nice features. It's nice having preset options for grounds consistency. My only issue is how hard it is to clean. There are so many crevices and movies parts. Typically, I expect that you would be able to wipe down the grinder after use. But due to so many corners and little pieces, only dishwasher or running water would able to clean this out.

This is my favorite coffee grinder. Although it is not a burr grinder, it does the job very well. I use it mostly for grinding espresso fine coffee, and it does the job in no time. I also grind nuts, almonds, flax seeds, cumin seeds and such in it, and that, too goes very well. I now have two, the last one had been in use for almost five years, and going strong. This one will be in service upstairs, so I won't have to carry my first one around anymore.
If you found my review helpful, please, let me know!
Not even one month later and it has stopped working. This thing sucks! Don't buy it! It's been used once a week since 4/21 and now it doesn't work at all.

reviews.reviewTitle: The settings work well enough for higher grinding amounts but when just doing 4 cups or so I like to pulse it to get most of grinds even
reviews.reviewText:
cheap. but quality.
had one years ago, and decided to buy again, and was pleasantly supersized by the price.

The settings work well enough for higher grinding amounts but when just doing 4 cups or so I like to pulse it to get most of grinds even.

Not a problem for a full 8-12 cups payload , settings work just fine here.

I like that this can be taken apart for cleaning,

Yeah you don't get the most amazing feature set (hardly any really) but for the price I find it an incredible value.

Blade grinders are very inconsistent with the grind but they are cheaper compared to a burr grinder. If youre looking for a simple grinder that will get the job done, I have no complaints regarding the product itself. You honestly get what you pay for when it comes to grinders.

This has to be the best grinder on the market for the price. I love the way this breaks down so you can not only take the top off to pour your coffee out, but to clean it. I find the scraper inside to be great help to get those grinds that want to just felt against the inside...loosens them up and gets them out. Variable speeds and its nice looking! Extra convenient is the cord storage underneath. NO it has a long cord...those that think its short is because they didn't take it out of the storage underneath! Great value, valuable product.

reviews.reviewTitle: First Time Grounder...? Grinder...? Whatever. Buy this!
reviews.reviewText: Bought this so I could switch to bean instead of ground. Black Rifle Coffee and a freedom press. Some good coffee! Consistent grounds when you figure out what settings you need. Cord wraps into the bottom of the grinder, its convenient. Cleaning is SUPER easy due to the tank, and tank lid coming off. Very happy with the purchase.

I've used it only once so far but it's easy to use. You really don't need instructions. Everything detached easily, it ground up the beans nicely. Bought this for my French press and it was worth the money.

We received this as a wedding gift. We have used it several times with Tully's whole bean and Eight O'Clock colombian whole bean coffees. We use the "do not overfill" guideline to pulse the beans to a medium ground because we use a drip coffeemaker. We have not had any problems with this product so far. It is easy to wash and makes grinding simple and easy. It is suitable for a household of 2-3 adults. If you are trying to grind coffee for a large amount of people, I would suggest buying a larger grinder. This only makes enough for 8-10 cups of coffee at a time, depending on the strength you desire. We like our coffee medium strong, so we use about 4-6 tablespoons per 6-8 cups. The only thing I would say I have noticed that may be a downer is that sometimes after pulsing the beans there will be like ONE single bean left un-ground. Otherwise, we love this product and enjoy using it.

reviews.reviewTitle: It works great. It has a very consistent grind
reviews.reviewText: I bought an earlier model of this about five or six years ago. Originally one of the plastic arms broke inside while I was spinning it to scrape out the coffee grounds. It managed to last for all these years until another one finally broke, so I bought this replacement. The only difference seems to be in the external design. So far, no breaks. It works great. It has a very consistent grind, which is why I bought it again.

reviews.reviewTitle: You get what you pay for
reviews.reviewText:
For a cheap coffee grinder it worked just fine. However, I'm not sure that changing the cup setting did much of anything.

Pros:
- it's cheap
- it gets the job done

Cons:
- It broke and stopped turning on after a few months of use
- volume feature didn't do much; I ended up just keeping it on the highest volume for everything

reviews.reviewTitle: Very cheaply made, gets hot after few seconds on.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is very cheap and hardly works. It takes forever to grind the beans. There are so many steps to remove the container from base, lid, etc. It gets hot to touch after grinding a few seconds. Wouldnt recommend. Better off spending more money and getting one that will last.

reviews.reviewTitle: some nice features, but still a blade grinder
reviews.reviewText: I bought this coffee grinder after the hand-me-down grind I inherited from my folks kept leaving grounds on the counter. Based on reviews this sounded like a great grinder and it does have some very nice features, like the removeable grinding chamber that allows you to pour the grounds into the filter or pot, without needing to pick up the whole machine. The "Chamber Maid" is also a nice feature to scrape the grounds off the side of the chamber. But it is still a blade grinder and as such, some coffee gets ground into dust, which leaves mud in the bottom of your cup if your using a press pot or a single cup drip maker like Bodum's Solo. I also found the "automatic" feature, which you can set to grind anywhere from 4-12 cups either Course, Medium or Fine, useless. Again, I wanted a course grind for my press pot, but set for 4 cups and course grounds, it ground my beans medium to fine, before shutting down. So it is back to grinding until it "sounds right" and using my 4 cup drip coffee maker with a paper filter, which takes away some of the taste, but results in mud-free cups of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: but will that make my grinds more finer? Looks like I'll be doing some trial and ...
reviews.reviewText: Ordered the Mr. Coffee electric grinder primarily for use with my french press. So far I have used it about 4 times and still not getting a consistent grind. I've noticed big chunks of beans mixed here and there after it automatically stops. I read a couple of reviewers say to rock it back and forth but that didn't work either. I may try increasing the cup size so that it will grind longer, but will that make my grinds more finer? Looks like I'll be doing some trial and error test until I get even consistency grinds. Overall the build quality is pretty good. The power cord maybe a little short for some people also.

Works great, easy to use, easy to clean, and grinds accurately. Use it for grinding coffee beans for our french press, so I mostly use the course setting. It's good for grinding your own spices too! Overall, a good product and I have no issues or complaints.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job but lacks consistency
reviews.reviewText: Does what it needs to pretty well, This is a good started grinder for basic use. You will not get great consistency but for the price it does a decent job. Combined with fresh beans, this can produce a great cup of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do it! Buy this one! a it will change your mornings!
reviews.reviewText: It's taken a little to get used to (more high tech than the "push down" ones) but it works wonders! No more overflow of coffee grounds into my pot, it automatically shuts off when it has reached the right "consistency" and I LOVE that it has an easily detached chamber for the grounds and also wipes the sides clean! No more flipping the whole darn thing over and having to smack it!

reviews.reviewTitle: for blade grinders this is the best: it has a built in timer to make ...
reviews.reviewText: dont be put-off by the price; for blade grinders this is the best: it has a built in timer to make consistent grinds, plus comes apart for easy cleaning / pouring into the machine.

Maybe I am not savvy enough with coffee grinders, but i just feel like this is a good coffee grinder. Nothing amazing. It gets the job done. I would recommend it for the average joe just trying to make a cup of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would be awesome, if it worked.
reviews.reviewText:
When my grinder arrived, I unpacked it and really liked it's overall look, and the job it did grinding coffee. But the next time I went to use it, no go. The unit had power, and I could see that cuz' of the LED indicators on it, but it just would not activate to grind coffee. Yes, I had everything attached. Yes, I had the lid on properly and was pushing down on the button. I banged it a couple of times and wiggled the power cord, and it decided to run for a couple more days. It finally decided enough was enough, and refused to run again. I sent it back to Amazon, and chose the replacement option. I have yet to receive the replacement unit, so I can't say I'm terribly happy with this particular product experience.

Now, while it did run, the coffee grinder did a really nice job. I particularly like the built-in bowl scraper.

I did not use this coffee grinder right away when I bought it as my other coffee grinder started working again before I received this one. However, we just tried to use it and it doesn't work at all. The lights don't even come on, so I'm guessing the power cord has become disconnected inside the machine. Everything is aligned properly and I've read the manual three times trying to understand if there was just something we missed, but alas, no coffee today.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does its job it is ok. Nothing more or less.
reviews.reviewText: Well ot works fine, not great ,not bad. Just does its job. The reason it gets 3 is 1. Its not easy to pour out into a car or coffee pot with out spilling it. 2. It always has leftover coffee that never seems to come out. 3 i need to shake ot from time to time to get it to cycle through and make it fine.

The coffee sticks to the side, even with the turny thingy that's supposed to get it off. It's hard to get all the coffee back out of the cup. I wasn't expecting to have to hold the button down as opposed to a one-time press. That's not such a big deal, though.

I love this grinder and that I don't have to stand around counting in my head for grinding my coffee beans. I also love that it comes apart for easy cleaning. What I don't like is that I have to select the same settings every time - it doesn't remember my last setting.
Nice enough at first went to us it today and it just burnt up only used it less than 20 times. Don't bother

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grind, great coffee when combined with Keurig and EzCup.
reviews.reviewText: Use it in Fine setting to fresh grind coffee for my Keurig (using an EZcup and filters to brew the coffee). Big savings. better for the environment, and *much* better coffee than prepackaged capsules. Only downside is the grind is not as consistent as a good burr grinder, but then it's a lot cheaper and works well for my purposes. The cleaning vanes on it help extract the coffee grounds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Im not much of a "coffee snob" but the extra shake is somewhat annoying. I like that all of the parts break ...
reviews.reviewText: As will most coffee grinders, the shaking method is required in order to produce an even grind. Im not much of a "coffee snob" but the extra shake is somewhat annoying. I like that all of the parts break off for easy cleaning and access though.

Grinds coffee as well as can be expected for a non-burr grinder. It has settings, but it's all a loose variation on a coarse grind. It will leave some pretty hefty chunks if you're grinding on coarse and a low cup count. But as I am using a french press, this is not a deal breaker for me. I use it near daily and have had no issues since buying it a number of months ago. It is what you pay for so don't expect a consistent grind and do expect to have some chunks. Even on the fine grind setting. All it does is grind longer. And with a fixed blade and fixed blade height, you're only going to get so "fine."

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is AMAZING for prepping the beans
reviews.reviewText: A key component to my morning routine. I only drink French Press coffee. This grinder is AMAZING for prepping the beans. It is cheap but powerful. No complaints. Worth the time and effort for a fresh brewed cup of Joe.

I bought this thing 4 years ago and it still grinds like the first day I used it. Simple design and easy to clean. Very easy to grind exactly what you need with measured grinding options. Would highly recommend to any coffee lover.
Bought for a Christmas gift, this made in china product has many problems. Primarily though, it doesn't grind the beans leaving huge chunks behind. I would not recommend this made in china product.

I grind coffee for our use here at home and, since I like to have fresh-ground coffee at work too, I also grind coffee to take there. So, I've used this grinder 3 to 4 times daily, on average, for the past 29 months. When it eventually quits (and it shows no signs of that!), I plan to order another just like it!

Stated briefly:
1) The price is right
2) It's easy to use, just set it for the amount of coffee you're grinding
3) It makes a very even grind, as good as the burr grinder it replaced
4) It's easy to fill and easy to empty

If you're looking for the most advanced, feature-packed grinder, then this one is probably not for you. For example, it's not "one-touch" - you have to hold the grind button down until it stops automatically. But if you're looking for an efficient, low-cost grinder, I highly recommend it!

Very dependable coffee grinder. Does leave a few chunks, but nothing of any significance. Preset run times for size and grind makes it easy to make a good cup of coffee. I only use it for single cups in my Aeropress, so I dont have an opinion about making grandmas fir multiple cups/pots of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love the easy open top--put the beans in
reviews.reviewText: I love the easy open top--put the beans in, close the lid, press grind, open the lid, out they come. No fuss, no muss, no stuck drawers. Awesome device, great price. This is my 4th one in five years--the other three were terrible and I chucked them. This one actually works well.

Of my presents received at Christmas time, this is perhaps my favorite. With the Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric coffee grinder, it takes the guessing out of the equation, giving you a great grind each and every time. The grinding chamber is removable from the motor assembly, so you can easily remove the residual grinds to your press/machine (the Chamber Maid Cleaning System really does assist with this effort, believe it or not). Also, since it's removable and is dishwasher friendly, cleaning it periodically is rather simplified. Finally, the fact that the grinding chamber is removable only adds to the fact that you can safely (and I emphasize the word SAFE) remove all of your grinds without worrying whether you accidentally turn it on at the same time. To further the safety feature, the access lid must be closed completely in order to turn it on in the first place.

I've had a grinder in times past, but always felt that it was difficult to determine when to stop it from grinding. With my old grinder (that I haven't used for years and is either in a landfill somewhere or lost in a box stuffed away in our basement), I would either get the grinds too fine or not enough. Depending on whether I was grinding for a drip machine, or just a simple French Press, it was difficult to get the grind just right.

To summarize, this is a great product, loaded with innovative and safety features which earn it a five star rating from me.

Pepperman

I bought this as a birthday present for my brother who absolutely loves coffee and works as a barista at Starbucks. For such a low price, he absolutely loves this. It of course does not compare to a burr grinder, but for such a low price, this is the best kind of blade grinder that we have ever used. I would either be using this for a Chemex or a French Press and the grind works quite well for both of those settings, but if you're looking to grind beans for espresso use, this is not the best you could find as the beans towards the bottom of the chamber will be espresso fine but the ones on top will be shy of that fine grind that you really need for espresso. That is the only reason one star has been taken away.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder and quieter than earlier version.
reviews.reviewText:
An improvement over my previous version. I have one of these grinders at my home and liked it enough that I bought one for my small vacation home. The original unit is great and relatively quiet, but I still worried I would wake others grinding my coffee (I'm an early riser). To my surprise, this unit is quite a bit quieter than my original. I was very pleased.
One bit of advice. The built in cleaning system is a nice touch but it will not remove all the grounds. I still use a small coffee brush to clean the remaining grounds. But I still like the cleaning system; it makes it much easier than just a brush alone.
I'm very pleased with this grinder and highly recommend it.

I slightly marked it down for two reasons. A lot of plastic on the grinder, I would like of seen a glass vessel but I guess that would be able to be knocked over and broken. And second the "Chamber Maid" cleaning system... A little useless one could do the same thing with a napkin.

This is probably my favorite grinder I have purchased. It is very easy to clean. I thought the choices for coarse or fine would not really matter but it does help a little. This grinder seems a little sturdier than some of my old ones, hopefully it will last longer.

This grinder requires you to hold down the grinder button the entire time the beans are being ground down. It doesnt automatically measure beans nor are you able to store beans in the grinder. Each time you want beans ground you have to measure it out, then grind them and hold down the button until it turns off. We have found we have to shake the grinder when it grinds in order to get the beans to grind completely and not have any unground beans remaining.

Had this coffee bean grinder for months now, its used every day sometimes 2-3 a day. Great for the price, the beans can be ground to different consistencies like fine or course. Does what you want it to without any issues, well worth the purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Had to buy this because we accidentally purchased whole bean ...
reviews.reviewText: Had to buy this because we accidentally purchased whole bean grounds from the store but my husband loves this. He can accurately measure out how much he wants to make and our coffee is so much fresher now that we have fresh coffee grounds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very easy to use with nice features
reviews.reviewText: Got this because I am a coffee snob and wanted fresh grounds for my drip maker and french press. You can finesse how fine you like the grounds and use only what you need. Very easy to use and the detachable cup is a nice feature.

Use this all the time. This is our second one. The first one I decided to put in some hardened DME and it broke it. Doh! Well I learned my lesson and purchased it again and will never repeat that mistake. Great grinder. Use it all the time since we do pressed coffee and like to buy whole beans. Def worth the purchase. Good price too.

reviews.reviewTitle: Failed first time it was used. Returned for refund.
reviews.reviewText:
I read many of the reviews here on Amazon for this (and other) grinders before making a purchase. Since I have owned several types (Braun has been the overall best) over the past 30 years, I knew what I was looking for. This one seemed to fit the bill: Less expensive, larger grinding volume, quieter, longer lasting, etc.

Well, I was disappointed with it. It took what seemed forever to grind the beans to the fine consistency necessary for our machine. Then, after grinding about two cups of beans (we keep a few days worth of the ground beans in an airtight container), it completely stopped working. I am not sure if it was defective or just not capable of grinding properly. I am thinking it was the latter.

I sent it back and am not taking a chance on another one of these. I'm looking to purchase a better quality unit.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... to grind up herbs into power and it works fantastic for that
reviews.reviewText: i bought this item to grind up herbs into power and it works fantastic for that. very easy to use, small footprint and it is also very attractive. ive tested it with milk thistle seeds, and it ground them into a very very fine powder. the plug wraps up in the bottom making it easier to store, the bucket pops off easily and it makes quick work of my seeds. i have not tested it with coffee as i am not a huge coffee drinker, maybe i will try some freshly ground coffee :)

While it's a serviceable coffee bean grinder, I find that when I try to grind the supposed maximum amount for 12 cups of coffee the grinds are uneven in size on the medium setting. I even have to pick out whole beans that end up unground! Add in the clunkiness of this device, and I'm just very disappointed.

I had high hopes for this grinder because of the great reviews. I used it twice and it just stopped working. By the time I realized it was no longer working, the allowable return date just passed, so i'm out of luck and out of a grinder. Not making this mistake again. Going to go with another model. So disappointing!!

I loved it while it worked! It ground my coffee perfectly, I had it for a couple weeks then I was making rice flour (which I had used it for before) and I guess I over filled it and the motor burned up. Which that was my own fault so I will definitely be ordering another one when I have the extra money!

Great little coffee grinder. Easy to use, easy to clean. Does not take up much space. I had one for many years, so I gave my daughter this one. There is nothing like freshly grinding your coffee before you brew it. The taste of beans really comes out. She always loved my coffee, and now she loves her coffee too!

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic Value - Decent grinder, low price.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder for use with my french press, because I wasn't ready to spend the kind of money you need for a burr grinder, and it works great for what it costs.

Pros
-Detachable chamber for easy pouring/filling/cleaning
-Dishwasher safe, makes cleaning a breeze, especially nice for keeping oils from building up and producing bitter coffee.
-Timed grinding helps to produce a uniform grind. (as much as a blade grinder can)
-The finer, dust-like, particles get stuck in the "Chamber Maid Cleaning System" which means less silt in my cup of french press.

Cons
-The "Chamber Maid Cleaning System" is a joke. It's a plastic scraper that sweeps the bottom of the chamber when you take the lid off, and still doesn't get everything. A firm thump with the palm of your hand is more effective for emptying the chamber.
-(See-Pros) The fine particles that get stuck in the cleaning system would mean a bit of unnecessary waste for filtered drip brewers.
-It's construction does not allow it to dry easily, which results in clumping if you don't dry it thoroughly on your own after cleaning.
-The flip-top on the lid seems unnecessary, and sometimes grinds get stuck in there.

Criticisms aside, I love this grinder.
