This grinder is advertised on the box that it is "programmable." It is NOT. The grinder grinds exactly the same no matter what type of grind you select. It's all in the amount of time you grind. The amount of cups relies on how many beans you add to it. I've been back and forth with Mr Coffee customer service, but they will not acknowledge all this. This grinder is exactly like any other grinder, although the others are less expensive. All I can say about this grinder is that it works, so far. Shameful to pull the wool over our eyes. Do yourself a favor and buy from a company that doesn't lie to you.

reviews.reviewTitle: You get what you pay for
reviews.reviewText:
The product is way more complicated than it needs to be. On top of that, it always leaves a few beans left to be grinder. ALWAYS. Even when I barely put any beans in, there are a few pieces left. In addition, it always creates a mess with the grinds - pieces get stuck to the lid when pouring out or simply fly out during the grinding process.

Look, for $15 youll get grinder coffee. But if you love coffee like I do, spend a bit more money for an electric grinder with a removable metal bowl. I ended up paying about $30 for the Aicok (prob some Chinese manufacturer) but couldnt be more happy with it.

If you cant afford it, then have fun with incomplete coffee grinds and cleaning the mess it leaves behind.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love my Mr Coffee Grinder and this is my second one!
reviews.reviewText: I have finally worn out my first one after a number of years of heavy use and have just ordered my second one. I had tried and worn out, much faster, a number of more expensive brands of coffee grinders and had actually gone to a hand turn one before getting this one. I love the Mr. Coffee grinder and had been dreading having to try a new type as I didn't expect to find one like my old one after so many years. I guess that this is one case where a good product doesn't get replaced by a new design just to make something 'new'. And ops, I didn't know until reading the reviews today about the stored cord at the bottom! I had rather liked the short cord and gotten used to it. It is easy to use, easy to clean, easy to put beans in and easy to pour them out. I am just so very happy to find that it is still available. I would give this product more stars if possible.

reviews.reviewTitle: OK at first, stopped working reliably within 2 months
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to replace a Krups coffee grinder that I gave away, over a decade old and still working perfectly. I would have given the Mr. Coffee 4, maybe 3, stars when I first received it. The settings are ok, but it's easier just to pay attention to a regular grinder. It's a bit messy when the top comes off if it's at the full 12 cup capacity. Two months later, it's very finicky when it wants to actually work; sliding them into place, nothing happens, so the cup has to be pushed a little one way, the lid a little another way, and keep fiddling until it starts. It's under warranty, which is great if I though it was work boxing up, buying postage, and waiting 4-6 weeks with no coffee maker, but no thanks.

reviews.reviewTitle: Reliable performance and uniform grounds for almost a decade.
reviews.reviewText:
I've found this grinder very capable for my weekend coffee for about eight years running. The grind and yield selectors are designed well so I only need to press each button once (I usually grind beans for 4 cups/coarse); the timer in the grinder gives me exactly what I want. The bowl and lid wash easily in the dishwasher (I give them a quick rinse in the sink first) and the cord-wrap in the base holds enough cord properly to reach my outlet and still store neatly in the cupboard. The indicator lights are easy to view and the unit doesn't show much wear after years of use. I'm also satisfied in the size--it's about the same size as a 16 fl oz travel mug. The grinding chamber is clear plastic with a stainless steel liner about 1/3 way up the side--this keeps the unit from becoming opaque plastic as this area is adjacent to the grinding blade where grounds would scour plastic (a very keen design choice).

My only complaint (but not serious enough to dissuade buyers) is the bowl-scraping "ChamberMaid" system--while it's designed to help loosen grounds that stick to the wall of the grinding chamber, the plastic ribs create additional spaces where grounds get trapped or stick to--I'd think choosing materials which avoid a static charge or have a non-stick surface inside the grinding chamber would accomplish the goal without creating more complexity and moving parts. I still use the feature to loosen grounds caught around the scraping ribs (after removing the grinding cup from the base, twisting the lid moves the ribs around the outside of the grinding chamber), but think the only reason I use it is that grounds stick to this feature--a simple tap would loosen any stuck grounds if the feature were omitted.

With this complaint aside, this grinder is: affordable, durable, creates uniform grounds, adjustable from fine to course, adjusts from grounds for 4 up to 16 cups of coffee, has a well-designed cord storage, the grinding cup is removable, cup & lid are dishwasher safe, and controls are simple to use.

reviews.reviewTitle: A really great coffee grinder! Highly recommended!
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned this grinder for nearly 2 years now and it works great every time without fail! It's easy to use and I love the removable cup so that you do not have to dump the entire grinder upside down to put grounds in filter. I also love the "scraper" feature that allows you to twist the lid before removing it so that you can loosen any find grounds that may get stuck to the sides and bottom when grinding.

The reason for only 4 stars is, I wish the lid had a better seal on it. I've also used it as a spice grinder and fresh dehydrated pepper grinder, which is really works extremely well for, but the VERY fine dust-like particles from spices and HOT peppers can escape the lid and get into the air easily even before you open it and it can be a real breath taker. This is NOT an issue with coffee grinding. I'm now looking into purchasing an actual spice grinder for future spice grinding. Other than that, this grinder, when used for it's intended purpose, is great.

11/10/15 Update:
Well, just as another reviewer said, after prolonged use, the little plastic arms inside start to show chipping and wear. I still can't complain about how well it stood up to everyday use for 2 years. I recently decided to retire this one to under the cabinet and bought a stainless steel grinder with removable cups.

reviews.reviewTitle: Is good except for couple things....
reviews.reviewText:
This was a birthday gift so I'm grateful I received it. For review's sake, it does a pretty good job of grinding. Don't care for the top hold down button to grind.
And what is it with these dumb engineers of kitchen appliances these days that make short electrical cords??
I hope they're reading this (yes you are DUMB), my Crock-Pot, coffee maker, and blender are all short cord. They should be 4 ft.
Overall the grinder is nice and will get good use out of it.

Two years ago I bought what I think is an earlier version of this IDS77 grinder. It has the same number, but it looks a bit different - we bought it on a whim from a local discount store's "I don't know why we have this stuff" shelf. We bought it specifically to use for grinding whole spices. I use it for that purpose 5 or more times each week. It's a really satisfactory spice grinder: even reduces whole coriander seeds to a pretty consistent fine grind. I bought it because it has a lift-out container, so that it and the lid can be easily washed, which is necessary if you're grinding different types of spices. It works like a charm!

A tip: to get whole spices ground to a fine powder, I find it works best for me to grind them with salt and/or sugar from my recipe.

The removable grinding basket is very convenient. It's great to just be able to schlep it over to the stove and empty into whatever I'm cooking. Often, if I'm adding salt or sugar at the same time, I'll grind these in with the spices: the added volume makes for a very even grind.

The cleaning arms are helpful, though not critical, I'd say.

Note: I do let any whole spices I've toasted cool a bit before grinding them, as I don't know how heat resistant the basket and cleaning arms might be and don't want to find out the hard way.

Though I love it, I'm not giving this particular grinder 5 stars for two reasons. The first is that we had a sort of hard start-up. It was difficult for a while (several months)to get the lids lined up into the "start" position correctly so that pressing the top bar would make the grinder go. This was more than a bit of a hassle. I also found myself having to press the bar in different places to make it run. I seriously thought of giving up on the machine, but liked the idea of this grinder too much to do that. Now, I'm glad I persevered. I don't have either problem any more: either the grinder has trained me, or I suspect that a little obstruction somewhere in the unit wore down. The other reason for knocking off a star that I wish the lid was easier to clean. Dust from the spices gets under the presser bar and be really hard to clean out. This is more a cosmetic issue than an operational one.

By the way, I never grind coffee and spices in the same grinder. Both items have too definite flavor and cost too much to be cross-contaminated by oils from the other.

I recommend this grinder, and am buying one of them as a Christmas gift for my friend who also enjoys cooking Indian dishes.

This grinder will eventually turn beans into grounds, but it's far from ideal. It's very loud. It has programmed buttons but they are basically meaningless. It grinds really unevenly, so you will have 3/4 powder and 1/4 basically whole beans. Like several others posted, I basically grind for a count of 10 or so, then shake it, grind again, keep looking to see the grind progress, and then eventually have something that will work to make coffee. I moved in with a friend who has the cheap Krups grinder. It's quiet, fast, and grinds evenly. I'm getting one of those when this dies.

reviews.reviewTitle: Semi-automatic grinding, lasts quite a long time!
reviews.reviewText:
Awesome coffee grinder! You have a choice from three different grind types: Course, Medium or Fine. Also choose how many cups worth of beans you want to grind. There is a chart on the side of the grinder for reference, but 2/3 cup of beans is good for the 12 cup grind. Once you've selected your grind type and quantity, just hold the button down and the grinder will automatically stop when the grind for that setting is complete. No having to guess if you've let it grind long enough or not. Has internal side scraper that you can rotate with your fingers to get all the ground coffee out.

Super easy to clean. I rinse and toss in the top rack of the dishwasher. Mine has lasted nearly two years and only now needs a new blade. Unfortunately I cannot find a blade replacement so I'm going to have to buy a new one. It will most likely be the newest Mr. Coffee grinder or another one of these.

reviews.reviewTitle: Reconsider buying the Mr Coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I can only assume the 4 or 5 stars given as reviews were written by employees of Mr Coffee because this grinder can only be described as CRAP.
I have ground my beans for about 30 years and after purchasing this product I want to tear my hair out from frustration.
The "grind" selector is useless. No matter what you choose, you get coarse grinds and if you want "fine" you have to keep restarting it about 3 or 4 times.
It is extremely messy to use and as a result I dread making my coffee in the morning. The coffe sticks to the inside and is almost impossible to get all the grinds out completely.
There is coffee all over my counter and god forbid you put 2 beans over the limit indicated........you can smell the motor burning.
I contacted Mr Coffee with my concerns and they basically ignored me after telling me they "value my opinion".
Save your money and buy a better product, even if you have to spend a few dollars more because you will be thorougly disappointed by this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: I got spoiled on a Hamilton Beach
reviews.reviewText:
I picked up a Hamilton Beach grinder at Goodwill for, like, $5. It had a a selector switch, cord that wound inside(GENIUS!) and the lid had measurements on it. You just fill, twist the cap, hit the On button and walk away.

This is pretty decent, however if you unplug it you lose your settings unless your settings are Medium and 8 cups. I'm not keen on leaving stuff plugged in and on my counter(waste of electricity and space). Not to happy about having to stand and hold the on button while it grinds, I liked being able to walk away and tend breakfast. Those two things are .5 stars each, maybe 1.5 stars total. But man I miss that wind up cord, that was just pure freaking genius.

But it does the job, it was cheap and I have it now so I'll keep it till it burns out. Or I find something better at a garage sale or thrift store. In that case I'll donate it to a friend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Going strong after over a year...
reviews.reviewText:
My wife and I received this coffee grinder as a gift over a year ago. At the time we were the typical pre-ground coffee drinkers.

Before I go on, I want to be really clear on this next point: After learning how to buy whole bean coffee and learning what kinds we like, we will never go back to buying the pre-ground stuff.

That said, let's talk about this grinder. We have the black one and it has a permanent home next to our coffee pot. It gets used at least once a day, sometimes twice. It has ground everything from Tanzanian Peaberry to Guatalaman Maragogype to Costa Rican coffees. It has performed quite well in all circumstances.

Use of this item is really simple. Put the lid on securely, pick your number of cups and grind conssitency (fine, medium, or course), then push the button down until the grinding stops. There's no counting, guessing, or anything complicated about it.

When it's done, you just dump the ground coffee into your filter and transfer it to the coffee pot. You can use the little side-arm slider things (moving them around in circles) to help get more of the coffee out, but I tend to just give it a couple of nice taps on the bottom and that does the trick.

Given how much this thing gets used, we've yet to see and major signs of wear or any signs that the blades are getting dull. Clean up is relatively easy. I usually rinse the lid and cup with water, then use a dishwand to quickly clean out the inside. It air dries in a couple hours.

All in all, I think it's a solid product. I'm sitting here on a random Sunday morning over a year after we got this and I felt compelled to jump on Amazon and do a review. It really is a simple, well-performing product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good and bad points. Ok for me.
reviews.reviewText:
I am jcslights husband and I'm the one who uses it. This is a miniature blender, not a true grinder, but can give close results to a grinder. The grind is not consistant. I like fine grind because I make SUN Brewed coffee like Sun brewed tea. It keeps all the flavor but leaves behind all the bitterness and acid of hot brewed coffee.

You will have to pick the chopper/grinder up and shake it because the coffee clumps on the sides and won't fall back down into the chop blade for further chopping. Unless you shake it the entire chop time, you can get as big as half size beans when it's done. This can be a little tricky because you have to hold down the power/grind switch at the same time.

I have had other chopper/grinders like this that did the same clumping so this is not something specific to this device. In a chopper/grinder design such as this, the grind cannot be consistant and uniform all the way through. But I do like the timer and the amount selectors. Although timers and selectors on this design won't give consistant grind size, it is a lot better than guessing like in similar chopper/grinders of this design without timers.

The "chamber maid" cleaning system is unique. It is like a built in scraper on the sides of the unit which help get out most of the coffee that has clumped to the sides.

For the price, you can't go wrong. To get consistancy requires adjustable grates and a different style of grinder, not a chopper. A really good grinder can go into the hundreds of dollars and unless you are a very picky afficianado, it isn't worth it. You can get a good grinder/roaster for about $300 and up but that's really for the amateur/pro barista. I would reccomend it to a friend with these caveates. For my purposes, I like it.

reviews.reviewTitle: 10 Years of Being Fantastic For Grinding Whole Nutmegs, Other Spices & Seeds
reviews.reviewText:
This little appliance is an indispensable time-&-effort saver for spice/seed grinding. For about 10 years, I've regularly used my IDS77 to grind whole nutmegs, flaxseed & chia seed, which can't be easy on its small motor. It works as well today as it did the 1st time I used it.

This grinder chews through whole nutmegs like a champ. To process them, I break them into smaller pieces with a mallet, grind on coarse setting, & freeze. The consistency's a little different from grated nutmeg, but the result has the same <incoming pun> grate taste.

Unlike some reviewers, I don't find the container to be a problem to clean. The 14-inch cord's a little short, but it's workable; in my small, appliance-packed kitchen, the shorter cord saves e space & cord-winding time.

I've been grinding my own coffee for years. However, for the last several, I've been using a grind & brew coffee maker so no seperate grinder. It died so I decided to forgo the combo and just go with a seperate grinder, way cheaper thats for sure.

I already had cheapy Rival that I'd bought from Walmart years ago but I was itchin' for something fancier. So I went to Target, saw the fancy Mr Coffee grinder with all the pretty lights and flip lid. It also timed the grind which the old Rival didn't and was the main thing I wanted.

So I took the fancy new grinder home, plugged 'er in (that was the first big disappointment, the cord is like 5" long). Checked out the pretty lights on the side that let you adjust the "timer" for how many cups and strength of coffee. You still have to hold the grind button down but it will automatically kick off at the appropriate time. Kinda like your electric tooth brush when you've been brushing long enough. As long as you don't accidentally let your finger off the button, then you have to start all over again.

Then I tried to figure out how the beans go into the bowl. I pushed and prodded, twisted and pulled and finally the flip lid opened and then the whole lid contraption came off. Seems you can do it either way but neither way is easy. You'd think the flip lid would be easy but the design simply sucks and I can't quite put my finger on why...OH I know why! Because your finger needs to flip it back and the little lever to do that is pointing to the sky making leverage to open the lid nearly impossible w/o both hands. And you've got to hold your mouth juuuust right to get that sucker to open.

So its got this clever "basket maid" or whatever the call it. Thought that was a cool idea to clean out the bowl but trust me, doesn't work that well. Coffee grounds now stick to it as well so you still have to bang the thing on the counter which is difficulte given the design of it. And getting the bowl back on the base can be easy or harder than heck, depens on how its feeling that day.

So. Long story short, I'm back to my cheapy Rival from Walmart and I LOVE it. Its been a few days and I had no idea how much I missed the simplicty of the Rival. You pull of the bowl lid, throw in the beans, grind til its...ground (why I thought this was hard I don't know), turn it over, tap tap on the counter and voila! Coffee's a brewin. The older I get, the more I love simplicity. So save your money and get a Rival.

I purchased this inexpensive coffee grinder knowing it wouldn't work as i grind a lot of coffee. I was very surprised to see that it actually works very well. Although it is noisy as most grinders seem to be, it was very well worth the money. It has setting indicator lights and different grind setting to go from coarse to fine, medium or regular. It can go in the dishwasher. It has a fully removable grinding chamber which grinds about a cup at a time. It has a polarized plug, one blade wider so it only fits into socket one way to help prevent against electric shock. The cord is long enough to reach the socket and short enough and easy to tuck in bottom of grinder when storing away. The only part out is the plug. Handy feature. After grinding its very easy to pour into storage container or directly into coffee pot filter. I use this grinder at least once a week and am very happy i bought it. I would recommend this grinder for coffee lovers who enjoy grinding different kinds of coffee beans like i do.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just buy a burr or an old shake n' time grinder
reviews.reviewText:
Summary: This product is fragile and less precise than less expensive models. If what you want is consistent control over the coarseness of your grind, burr grinders are the way to go. If what you want is something inexpensive that will get the job done, you can do better for cheaper. Someone wrote a glowing review of this product who disapproves of burr grinders, but I have just switched to a cheap burr grinder (Cuisinart DBM-8) from this product and my pressed coffee has never tasted better. I'll try to be a bit more specific. I would like to argue that this product is ill-suited for almost any coffee-grinding needs.

The goal of this product is to give you the control over grinding your coffee that resembles that of a burr grinder but at the price and convenience of a small blade grinder. It aims to accomplish this goal by featuring three spinning columns along the inside wall of the cup. When you grind the coffee these columns spin to keep the coffee moving onto the blade so that the beans grind consistently regardless of the speed at which the blade spins. Then, by selecting one of three settings on the device, the blade will spin more or less quickly so as to grind the beans more or less finely. (There is a second setting for how much coffee you want to grind that affects the overall duration of the grinding session.) In theory, therefore, the grinder should give you moderate control over the coarseness of your grind while all you have to do is make the appropriate selection and press the "on" button.

However, these spinning columns accomplish no more than what can be accomplished by a $10 coffee grinder and a good shaking. So, the question is whether it's worth the extra money to have a grinder that changes the speed of the blade.

The main problem with this grinder in practice is that the speed-variation and stirring are utterly insufficient to grind the coffee medium-coarse (for a conic drip coffee maker) to coarse (for a press), which, incidentally, is all I ever wanted from the device. Gravity overpowers the stirring and tends to produce sedimentary layers of more to less ground coffee. This inconsistency is the worst problem you can have with a coffee grinder, in my opinion at least. For a press for example, any amount of very finely ground coffee will produce a tannin-embittered sludge at the bottom of your press/cup. This makes the final portion of your batch of coffee undrinkable, and makes the rest of it spoil more quickly. One might try to solve this problem, as my roommates have, by shaking the coffee grinder in addition to selecting its settings. But this quickly reveals two things: (1) Shaking the coffee and grinding it for a set amount of time actually can be found to exhibit more control over the grind than the settings (you can, e.g., set it to fine, shake it, and just not grind it as long and accomplish the same thing as setting it to coarse and grinding it longer); and (2) Shaking the coffee grinder appears to cause the plastic stirring columns to break. My grinder broke within a year, presumably because of shaking.

If shaking the coffee grinder gets one more consistency and control than the automatic control settings, then there is no reason to buy a grinder with such settings. Just buy a cheap one and learn the art of shaking and timing. Further, once the columns break (whether they will so easily when the product is not shaken, I cannot say), the stirring function is useless and the coffee is hopelessly inconsistent. So, if the main selling point of the product is so limited in life-span, then why not spend a little more money on a burr grinder which will last much longer.

Getting down to the bottom-line, I think that what coffee grinder you purchase will depend primarily on how you intend to make your coffee. If you want medium-coarse coffee for a conic-filtered drip machine, I don't see any reason to be dissatisfied with the shake n' time method and a cheap grinder. If you happen to want medium-fine ground coffee for a cheaper machine and you're willing to resist the temptation to shake this grinder AND you want the convenience of not having to shake, then maybe this grinder will suit your needs. But if you want pressed coffee, the burr grinder is hands down the only sufficient way to go. Moreover, since the burr grinder will also give you at least equal (but I would argue better) results for the other methods of brewing just described, the only reason I see not to buy it is because you want to save $30 and get an arm workout. [Note: I've ignored the issue of espresso grinding which readers of these reviews will appreciate is a more complicated issue.]

So I've had this grinder 3 years now, and it still works GREAT. The blades are sharp and functional, the plastic is all intact. There is some scuffing on the clear cup, but that's expected when grinding things. We use this every day, sometimes twice a day, to grind course coffee for an 8 cup french press. It gets a workout.

Issues: If you washed out the residue by hand, there wouldn't be any issues. I'd call this the perfect grinder at this price point. However, since you need to clean this, and it claims the grinding cup is dishwasher safe, I must regretfully say it's not quite perfect. If you put this through the dishwasher, bits of grit and stuff, that should wash down the drain, will get trapped between the outside of the metal cup and the plastic frame. There is apparently enough room for water to get between here, but not for any sort of cleaning brush to get rid of the trapped mess. It begins to look awful and recently, I noticed that the trapped bits of food are growing mold threads. I've run this through the DW numerous times, usually every few uses. It's frankly gross that they built this in such a way to trap food, without a way to disconnect the metal cup and the plastic housing to clean between them. But like I said, if you wash the bowl out by hand, it should be just fine.

All in all, a good grinder, just not Dishwasher Safe.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great For Fine Grinds And Not So Great For Consistant Coarse Grinds
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is actually not bad for the money and would be ideal for those who are looking for a nice fine grind which this does fairly well. Where it loses me is the fact that the coarse grind, which is preferred for using with French Presses, is so uneven that it's hard to believe anyone really uses it for a coarse grind.

The unit itself seems well built and it is easy to use and clean. For finely grinding beans I like it a lot. For coarse grinding not so much. Overall this is a decent grinder for the price, especially for those looking to use normal drip machines or the individual fillable k-cups.

My wife (and kids) bought me this for Father's day. After reading the reviews here, I was unsure what to expect (some loved, some didn't).
First, the cord is too short. I have to move the grinder up against the counter back splash in order to reach the outlet. And even at that point, it just barely reaches the bottom outlet.
Second, I've ground beans 3 times now and it's actually gotten progressively worse. The first time, I had a couple of whole beans left after grinding (which is somewhat acceptable). By this 3rd time, I had at least 5-7 beans that hadn't even been touched - still whole. And there were literally another 10 or so beans that were merely cut in half or thirds. The little plastic "sweeper" they have seems to jam from the grinds after just a few seconds of grinding. Once that happens, there is nothing moving the beans around other than the blades. I believe that it where the inconsistency is coming from. Just a guess on my part.
Overall, I could not recommend this grinder to anyone with a straight face. Sure if you want something cheap, it "kind of" does the job, but not really. There are many other $20 grinders out there that would be a better choice.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after only a month of use
reviews.reviewText:
I was somewhat disappointed in this grinder from the start. Things that bothered me:

The "chamber maid" system does not work. Grounds still stick to the bottom, and they're harder to clear out with the plastic mechanism in the way.
The lid is designed to allow you to simply lift and pour grounds out, but that doesn't work well either. You have to take the top off and pour that way to get all of the grounds out. That's easy enough to do, of course, but I find it annoying that it doesn't work as intended.
The timer for the grind is way off - you have to keep an eye on the coffee yourself to make sure it's not too finely ground. This is another thing that is easy enough to do, but why put a timer on the thing if it's not going to do its job?
It sometimes took me a couple of tries to get the top locked in place so that I could start the grind. It's just a bit clumsy, which was never an issue with my previous grinder.

Despite all that, the grinder still ground coffee, which was its primary job, so I kept using it daily anyway. Unfortunately, the motor stopped and it refused to grind any more after only a month of use, so now it doesn't even have that going for it. I hate to throw this hunk of plastic in the trash after such a short time, but I guess that's where it belongs.

I am a coffee snob. I have my own home/commercial Barista Machine, A LOT of different beans for different tastes and I have a kitchen that looks like a professional coffee bar...and up until about 3 months ago, I was quite happy with my little inexpensive Mr. Coffee grinder, that I have been using for YEARS! Unfortunately, I trustingly replaced it with the same one from my local Target store. OH MY GOODNESS! They changed the blade style, and perhaps lowered the power of the motor because it does NOT come close to the one that sat upon my counter for all those years, before dying to it's last bean. EVERY time I have used it, I have to shake and run it a couple more times as the beans are NEVER all ground. So disappointing. I am ordering the Epica tonight that I have heard many good things about.

reviews.reviewTitle: ridiculously short cord - I have to use an extension cord
reviews.reviewText:
When my old coffee grinder conked out, I picked up one of these in my local Target store. It looked like it was very function, with precision brewing for between 4-12 cups and three grind settings. However, the cord is less than two inches long so if you have a kitchen where your counter has a backsplash, you will need to get an extension cord to use your coffee mill.

It does come apart easy and it grinds quickly. However, the medium grind does grind beans coarsely, and I do not consider that to be a medium grind at all. Even after two cycles, some beans were still in large chunks. I did learn that when it says do not fill past this line, it means it and I got a better grind by not filling it as high as the fill line. However, on medium it still gives a course grind so I use the fine setting and it works perfectly.

If the cord length, or lack thereof, is not an issue, this is a good coffee grinder, just use the fine setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: OK for coffee, Perfect for spices
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this grinder a few years ago and thought ti was only so so for coffee( definitely not the best) However as a spice grinder it is fantastic, grinds them just the way you like. easy to see the coarseness. The sidewall cleaning feature is great all in all the perfect spice grinder, and ironically it doesn't show up when you search spice grinders on amazon.

I have had this for about 2 years but only used it maybe 15x or less. It worked fine and the performance was great until I went to use one day and it had just stopped working. The green lights still light up but nothing happens when I try to grind. For using so little I'd think it would last years and years. Oh well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cheap, small, and easy to clean
reviews.reviewText: Very inexpensive coffee grinder which is easy to clean. I have been using my ninja blender to grind my beans. This works but it is a hassle being so large and a chore to clean. This coffee grinder works well enough and is super easy to clean. The cap and bowl both come off and clean up nicely using a brush and water. It did leave a couple of larger bean pieces but hey this thing only set me back $14 so I can't really ask for too much.

reviews.reviewTitle: It works great, but I'm just annoyed that I have to ...
reviews.reviewText: It works great, but I'm just annoyed that I have to stand there and hold it while it does its thing for 20 seconds. Might as well just hand grind my coffee. Also, when it's unplugged it forgets its settings so I'm constantly having to adjust it to my preferred grind. I definitely recommend passing up on this and spending the money on a higher end hand grinder

I bought an unit about 2+ years ago and after 2+ years of daily use, the chamber cleaning thingie broke, so I bought a replacement. To my surprise, they must have revised the plastic molding design because the lid does not have a good seal when closed. I have the old broken unit and new unit side by side and it's very clear there is a visible gap near the sprout on the new unit when the lid is fully closed! Why do I complain? Because I usually give it a light shake during grinding to loose grinds that stuck to one side. With this open gap, a light shake would cause grinds to come out of the chamber. In fact, it have not had a single session that I didn't need to clean up my kitchen counter because of the escaped grinds.

I took the new unit back and swapped it and same issue on the second unit, which leads me to believe the plastic molding design got changed for the worse.

I never realized how good my Mr Coffee IDS77 is at home until i started using a Black & Decker CBM210 (burr grinder) at work. We bought the B&D CBM210 brand new and it was quickly terrible.

I've used the MC IDS77 for months and had no issues at all. The MC IDS77 is faster to work with & less of a mess/pita compared to the B&D CBM210.

I shake the IDS77 around a little bit while grinding, remove the (top &) container and pound it out into the basket. Works like a charm. This takes care of any uneven grind, extra @ the bottom and keeps things tidy.

I find the B&D CBM210's static charged container to be annoying & cheap. So far there's always a little bit of a mess. Maybe i'll figure out a 'method' for that.

Everything bad everyone has said about the B&D CBM210 seems accurate.

I'll be keeping my MC IDS77 :)

Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric Coffee Grinder with Chamber Maid Cleaning System, Black

Black & Decker CBM210 Stainless Steel Burr Coffee Mill/Grinder

Normally I buy ground coffee, but I've seen some interesting varieties sold as whole beans in the supermarket. This grinder gets the job done, providing a good consistent grind for my automatic coffee maker. Rather than grinding the beans daily, I grind the entire bag when I get it and store the coffee grinds in a sealed container in my refrigerator. This grinder isn't big enough to do a whole bag at once, so I do need to go through the routine a few times. I just leave the settings on "12 cup" and "medium", put in the beans in, hold the "on" button til the grinding stops, and empty it. Even after unplugging it and then plugging it back in, it still keeps the last setting. The top comes off easily, allowing for easy pouring without spillage. The first time I used it, I briefly thought it wasn't working; however, I soon realized the top container wasn't lined up properly and turning it a little got it going. I've now used the grinder for a few bags without any other problems.

After my old Hamilton Beach grinder broke (because I dropped it) I looked hard for a new one. I should have just bought another Hamilton Beach!

I know I should start with the positive, but there are none. The cord is short and takes forever to put back into the cord storage. It leaves my fingers bruised. The lid flap is too floppy and with the slightest tilt it spills the coffee. Not to mention that it does not keep the flavor sealed in the cup. To turn the grinder on, you have to press really hard on one particular spot and hold for dear life. If you slightly release the pressure, the grinder stops and thus loses the selection of the amount and grind of coffee. Then the coffee grind is very uneven. While some coffee is finely ground, there are still beans that are just cut in half, or are chunky. And then comes the worse part of snapping the cup and lid on properly. The twist and lock is a great invention, but to have two of those on the same machine is quite too much. Trying to align the grooves is so frustrating, that I just want to fling it across the kitchen into the trash.

I bought mine at a local store and I will take it back!!!

I will keep this short. I have found the same issues as many here have pointed out. The sweep arms don't work well and only serve to get in the way of cleaning with a brush. The cord windup feature is a stunt in itself and isn't worth the effort. The grind is inconsistent - even for a blade-type grinder. The alignment to close the lid can be a pain. And my newest problem with this grinder is that the plastic chamber deforms after a while and the lid tracks don't hold tight anymore. I have to twist-latch the lid and then hold it tight to ensure it doesn't slip off. In fairness, the grinder has worked to grind coffee every morning for about 6 months with no issues outside of the over-thought under-executed engineering. This was an emergency replacement for my previous grinder, but I can already see myself buying another grinder very soon; a pity, considering the motor, selectors, and timer all seem to be fine.

I bought this on impulse to see if the chamber maid features would be cleaner to use than my cheap grinders. Fail. Both the grind chamber and the top piece have a twist open construction that wastes a few seconds of fussing, but the real problem is the top piece which has a hinged flap perfectly designed to dump dust all over my counter. There is no useful reason for having that flap. I also have not found a way to pour from the grind chamber in a way that empties the chamber without again getting dust all over. And the grind quality is no better than the cheaper and simpler units.

reviews.reviewTitle: Used for Spice Grinding and died and he second time...
reviews.reviewText: Worked twice and then the motor died. Does not operate anymore. Full disclosure, I used it to grind spice not coffee. I had an older mr coffee, been using it for 10 years and finally dying, still not completely dead. So I thought I would replace that with this one. Bad decision, not everything that shines is diamond. I will purchase the regular non fancy mr coffee grinder, at least for the purpose of grinding spices.

For the price I would say this coffee grinder is pretty good. There are several "options" as far as the number of cups and coarseness goes, but I've found them pretty useless. I find that even on "coarse" I still like my coffee coarser than the end result if you trust the auto shut off feature of the system. If you like a fine or medium ground though you won't have an issue.

What's really nice about this grinder is that the lid, and the part that holds and grinds the beans comes apart from the main unit making it pretty easy to clean. The chambermaid cleaning system is ok... it does help get some of the grinds off of the sides and bottom but it makes it a bit hard to clean the chamber.

Overall I like the grinder and it is the right price. If you want something more sophisticated or precise you will probably have to pay more but this thing gets the job done.

Used this grinder 3x per week for 9 months to grind my coffee. Today, I go to do my usual routine and it won't turn on. I spot a small deformation in the plastic, which I press with my finger. Immediately, plastic starts burning and smoke starts rising from the melting material.

If your product is going to fail, try not to let it fail in a way that burns the consumer and starts melting plastic. Just a suggestion.

When I look for a coffee grinder, I look for 4 things:

1) Noise: This grinder is fairly noisy, but then again, so are most grinders. On a scale of 1-10 as far as noisyness goes compared to other grinders, I'd give it a 7.

2) Consistency: I like to grind my coffee coarse for french press; this grinder isn't very good at making a consistent coarse grind. However, if you want a regular grind for drip coffee or a fine grind for expresso, it does a really good job at that.

3) Static: I hate it whenever you pull the top off of a grinder to get the coffee out and tiny grind go flying everywhere--I've never had a problem with this grinder. You can open the top and pour the grinds out (which is difficult to do if you're trying to get it into a small container because the spout itself is not much different from the lip of a cup) or you can scoop the grinds out, which I preferto do anyway to double measure stuff (old habit).

4) Cleaning: This grinder has a removable top that you can take apart, which makes cleaning very easy. It also says it has a "Chaimber Maid" system...all that is is three thin plastic "claws" that hug the inside of the grinding chamber which you rotate awkwardly so that they scrape the sides of the chamber. It's neat, but unnecessary.

Other features:

There is a "cord storage" system that is a bit of a hassle to use because it requires you to coil the cord into a groove under the grinder (when you get the grinder only a short bit of the cord is shown, and the rest is coiled. It doesn't look like you can uncoil the cord from down there, and unless you're crazy enough to pull the cord out of your brand new grinder you'll have no clue that the thing is actually 37 inches long)

It has an "auto off" feature...I've never used it because my grindes always reach the coarsness I like before the timer shuts off the grinder.

The measuring system that the grinder uses is marked on the sid of the grinder which is very helpful (you don't have to pull out the manual every time you want to know how many Tbsp of coffee you need to make # cups of coffee)

It's about 8 in. tall with the diameter at the top being 4 in. (it's wider at the top).

Overall:

I like the grinder. I'd rather have a pull-cord-storage and a quieter grinder, but for the price that I paid, I'm a happy customer.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... past one year and i must say it works pretty good. It grinds the coffee finely
reviews.reviewText:
i am using this product since the past one year and i must say it works pretty good.
It grinds the coffee finely. and with ease.
I not only use it to just grind coffee but any dry spices. Its complete lifesaver for me.
I deducted one star from my ratings because its a little difficult to clean this. The parts do come off but the cup doesnt clean too well. Even so it doesnt matter too much as these are all dry ingredients. Only do not try mixing ground paprika with coffee

I've had a lot of different coffee grinders and I do have to say that this one it actually grinds very nicely to a fine powder to a very coarse grind of coffee I put it through its ringer since I have had it and it's worth the money definitely a good buy

reviews.reviewTitle: The best ive used in 25 yrs
reviews.reviewText: I've been using this Grinder near 10 fricken years. My mother whom I bought one for six months after my first one has been using it the longest. I'm on my second only because of the $15 price I gave it away before my move . after all this time I. Still unsure if the setting gs work. But I k ow if you fill it under the line full you make 12cups and so fourth. It's loud but it grinds well and its nice to not have to shake the grinds while grinding. Just hold button and as long as you don't over fill past the line it grinds it to a good grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: nor is there a reset or easy access to a fuse
reviews.reviewText:
Impressed with the variety of grinds and does a fairly decent job at matching the time to coarseness ratio. Also reasonably priced.
However, just under a dozen times, and although it still has power (lights are on), it will not grind. Users manual says a potential overload on grind quantity. Screws are not visible to open and check, nor is there a reset or easy access to a fuse. Can turn the grind wheel with no over resistance by hand.
Would recommend looking for grinders with a reservoir for beans, they are very little more in cost. A burr grinder would decrease undue load on the motor, and save this headache.

We purchased this grinder less than a year ago and it worked well. But eventually, the plastic of the cleaning basket wore out. I had read other reviews here and noted that others had called Mr. Coffee about this and recieved a replacement basket from them for free. So with this information, I called Mr. Coffee, but they were out of replacement baskets. To my surprise, they sent me a hole new grinder, absolutely FREE. It was a BMH23 Automatic Burr Mill Grinder, which was much better quality than the one I had. Kudos to Mr. Coffee's customer service. This kind of service creates satisfied customers. I will write a review on the new one after I have used it for a while.

True, I've had this grinder for about a year and a half, but the plastic 'cleaner' inside the bean chamber broke this morning. I called Mr. Coffee and they do not make this model anymore so the chamber is not replaceable. I didn't use it everyday, so I feel it should not have broken. That little plastic piece really isn't even necessary.The motor is fine...what a waste. They told me I have to buy a whole new one. It won't be a Mr. Coffee brand.

I use fresh ground whole bean coffee and a corningware percolator, sometimes french press - judge me how you will.

This is an exceedingly versatile grinder. I do not have experience with more advanced (expensive) systems, but have used a few of the other cheapies, and this one is superior to most. When taking off the lid, I have no problem with spilling grounds on the countertop as with some and the consistency is fairly good, unless grinding too coarse which results in some larger bean chunks.

A solution to this problem, which I learned from a friend who works at a reputable Pittsburgh coffee shop, is to actually pick up and shake the grinder while grinding. This results in a much more even grinding yield.

The bean chamber scraping system is a huge plus.

All in all, I give it an A+.

I didn't find mine on amazon but I don't care what these other reviews are saying. I've had this grinder for years and it has been the best thing ever. Compact, easy to use and is still working, best thing ever in my opinion.

We have had two of these in the past 6 years. the first one started to have an issue a few months back...the grounds would fall out of the chamber area as you twist the top chamber to then move the grounds to the coffee maker. Since our other one was several years old we just decided to buy another one. We liked it, it does a great job, so why not buy another. Now we open the box on the second one just before the Thanksgiving holidays and encountered exactly the same issue with the new one. We purchased at Walmart, but won't be buying another one based on this reason and the explanation below of our phone experience with Mr. Coffee.

I literally just got off the phone with Vanessa at Mr. Coffee. She could offer no help as the date code on the prongs was out of range for ANY warranty service. Even if I provided a copy of the receipt to her...she could not help...it must go back to the retailer. EVEN WITHIN THE 1 YEAR OF WARRANTY. It took a few attempts at asking in a different way to get that answer. I asked if there is a known issue regarding the grounds 'leaking out' from just under where the "Push On" button is located, but I got a standard "No we don't have that problem on our grinders"...well obviously you do.

Retailers buy these in bulk and who knows about the date code and inventory...but Mr. Coffee could offer no help what so ever...they just had a standard template of questions and no technical assistance. So because of that we will not waste our time buying another one (which could have the same issue) and run around to get a headache. We will just buy another brand with better reviews.

My attempt to upload a video hasn't been all that successful. I have however spent $5 on food grade silicone sealer to remedy the issue. Under the 'button' you press down to start the grind is a huge void that collects grounds due to a design flaw. Packing it with the food grade silicone prevents the grounds from filling the void and then falling out when you twist the cap.

This is a rubbish grinder. Over-engineered in my view. My wife bought it to replace an old Krups that after 20 years gave up the ghost. A couple of days after I first got it, it mysteriously stopped working. Sure, check the contact button at the top, make sure that the button it depresses depresses, plugged in to a live outlet yah dah yah dah. No grinding action at all. OK, try cycling through all of the settings (too many in my view. At best should be just coarse, medium and fine), combined with each of the cup settings. Voila, an instant useless piece of junk....

Then, mysteriously, when I tried it again, it worked. Great....no problems for several weeks, but then two days ago, it ceased working. Tried all the various settings etc etc, but it's back to it's dormant self. I suspect it has to do with the auto-off feature that is not explained in the manual. Neither are there instructions how to reset. For the $ 20 or so we paid for this, it has certainly provided its value in terms of inconvenience and irritation. Granted, it is a lot easier to clean since it is not in use.

Don't waste your money. Buy a Krups, or any other grinder that grinds and does not have a bunch of settings (likely to fail in time, particularly with finely ground dust.Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric Coffee Grinder with Chamber Maid Cleaning System, Black

reviews.reviewTitle: Too many parts inside cup.Coffee gets stuck.
reviews.reviewText:
This silly grinder has too many parts inside the cup. The parts are supposed to help clean out the cup. Instead, they actually help to hold coffee grounds in the cup. The lid even holds grounds. There are way too many contours in the cup. It cannot possibly be cleaned out. At all.

Also, you actually have to stand there and hold a button down to operate the grinder. You can't walk away and get your lunch ready. You can't do anything, if it would require you to walk away from the grinder. How is this a good idea? Why in the world can't they have a switch that you turn on and walk away? It could turn itself off automatically, (We know this because that's what it does now; It turns itself off automatically).

Summary - Pros: Cheap. <$20 Cons: Does not empty completely. Lots of extra plastic parts. User has to stand by it and hold button down to operate.

I bought this machine because it was a Mr. Coffee and for the price. My Mr. Coffee coffee brewers last until I HAVE to throw them out just because they're so old. No so with this grinder. After a few months of grinding one cup of coffee a day, it broke. While it lasted, it did a pretty good job but the beans were not always ground completely. Plus it was a bear to clean. Now I have to buy another one which means that if I had spent a little more money on it initially, I wouldn't have to go out and buy another one. You get what you pay for. UPDATE: I ended up buying a more expensive Mr. Coffee because I like the brand. I bought the Burr Mill BMH Series. #1: IT'S LOUD! But I figured I could put up with that for the small amount of time it's running (except when you have company and the bedroom is right next to the kitchen). It did a good job grinding the beans. #2: The lid on the Grinding Chamber has an inset for a small scoop/cleaning brush. When you grind the beans, the ground beans get blown onto this lid inside the chamber (understand?) and it's a real pain to clean. #3: I hadn't even had it a year yet and one morning I didn't get the amount of ground beans that I had dialed - and used every day. I figured it needed to be cleaned so I took it apart and cleaned it per the instructions. It worked - for about two weeks. It's now back to not grinding the amount of beans I dialed. I plan on calling Mr. Coffee tomorrow to see what they have to say but if it has to be sent back to be fixed, it's not worth the hassle. And then what do I use to grind my beans while it's gone? It would be easier to just go out and buy a new one but it won't be another Mr. Coffee. I'm disappointed because it did a good job for the short time it worked. Perhaps Mr. Coffee should just stick to Coffee Makers.

lets start with the dull blade that grinds unevenly
then the super loud motor noise
then the led lights that remain on all the time except when unplugged and then you have to reset grind
then the on/off button that only works half the time unless you hold the lid closed while pressing button
then the short cord
don't buy.....

reviews.reviewTitle: Cord length makes it almost unusable
reviews.reviewText: This is my second one of these. I liked it enough after the plastic piece that scrapes the coffee off the edge of the grinder that I bought another one. The cord on my original one was short. The cord length on the new one makes it almost unusable. It is 6" long including the plug. I would give this 4 or 5 stars, but the cheapness of shortening the cord to that length pisses me off enough to give it only 2 stars.

Been using grinder for two weeks now and it works great. It is easy to use and clean. It is a bit loud but I'm sure grinders are supposed to be noisey. I would highly recommend. Great ginder at an affordable price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Was purchased at K-mart and love it! I have really enjoyed fresh ground coffee ...
reviews.reviewText: Was purchased at K-mart and love it! I have really enjoyed fresh ground coffee beans, both in smell and taste. This is small, so it doesn't take up an inordinate amount of counter space. I had accidentally purchased unground bean coffee at my local grocery store and wasn't about to return to grind it in their grinder, so I requested this as an "early" Christmas present, and love it!

In the morning, after the usual progression of caffeine addiction brings me to the kitchen, I find myself shouting "Who designed this crap?" That's because I'm trying to use the Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric Coffee Grinder with Chamber Maid Cleaning System.

First off, this unit's crowning feature is the Chamber Maid Cleaning System, which I take to mean the cheap plastic arms that used to be inside the grinding chamber. Notice past-tense, a few grinds after purchasing this device the arms broke and were ground up with the rest of the coffee grounds. And no, I of course didn't notice I was brewing a teaspoon of black plastic powder with my coffee. It's fortunate that I don't care enough about spotless appliances to be grieved by the loss of the plastic arms (which did in fact remove about half the coffee powder from the chamber walls, if I remember right.)

Second feature I don't understand, the lid. The device has a fundamentally simple function; you add coffee beans, press a button, remove coffee powder. The button is fine, but the adding and removing is greatly hampered by what appears to be a futuristic pod bay door with a window and another door inside it. The interior clear plastic door thingy flaps loosely and doesn't remove completely, which distributes coffee powder throughout your counter tops. But this is totally unnecessary because you can easily unscrew the whole lid and actually remove the majority of coffee powder. Just be careful when you put the lid down somewhere as the inner door could swing open and distribute coffee powder.

All things considered, after removing the broken body of Chamber Maid and duct-taping the "door" shut, it does grind coffee beans. 2 stars.

This was my first coffee grinder and I'm happy with it's performance and features. I would have given it 5 stars if the material quality felt a little better. It feels like the chamber might break or wear out but only time will tell that for sure. I really like the settings for the grind and how that is automatic. You can wrap the cord inside the bottom of the device so that you only have the length of cord you need available and you can wrap the cord back up each time if you wanted and it makes storage in the cabinet easy for me. That auto timing and settings make this grinder worth the extra over a regular entry level grinder. Much better price than a mill grinder and in my opinion the assortment of settings makes this unit better.

This thing is a bit complicated for a basic coffee grinder. I paid more for it because the outer package said "Auto-Off Feature". That claim is deceptive. It requires you to manually compress the grinder button until the beans are ground. It stops grinding when your selected grind-choice is reached. You cannot start this grinder and then walk away to do something else.

On top of that, it doesn't grind evenly. The resulting grind has a variety of chunks, slivers and fine powder regardless of how you set the controls.

The lights stay on 24/7 unless you unplug the grinder from the wall.

The beans are added and removed by raising the spout in the cap. When you want to clean the grinder, you have to twist the bowl (not to be confused with the cap) to the unlock position. Be careful not to squeeze too hard or you'll crack the thin plastic. Pull the basket straight up, remove the bowl and place it and the cap in the dishwasher. It's easier to just leave the bowl and cap attached and wipe everything down with a damp dishcloth.

Sometimes less is more. This grinder with its phony "auto-off" feature and removable bowl isn't worth the extra money.

I have a Krups chopper-type coffee grinder that works okay, but I wanted a mill-type grinder that would produce more uniformly-sized grind. The box of this Mr. Coffee product specifically described this as a "mill", so I bought it. First disappointment: it isn't a mill, it's another chopper. Second disappointment: as a chopper it is far worse than the Krups I already own. Third disappointment: the so-called settings are just timers that shut the thing off after a preset amount of time, and not even very consistent timers. Sometimes they chop for 9 seconds and another time, on the same setting, decide to hang on for 12 seconds. The "coarse" setting, which I first tried, because I use a French press coffee maker, is so crude that some of the beans don't get chopped at all. Through trial and error, I discovered that to chop beans for a 3 cup Bodum, I needed to set the grinder to medium grind, 6 cups, and even there, it sometimes requires extra time to chop the beans.

The only feature that I consider worthwhile is the "chambermaid", which does do a decent job of loosening the ground coffee from chamber. Otherwise, the grinder is a rip-off, even at its low price. If this is your price range, just buy a regular chopper. My Krups, which is so old it doesn't even have a polarized plug, still does a better job of chopping up beans than the Mr. Coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder but has minor flaw
reviews.reviewText: We bought this grinder over a year ago, it worked great, but there is a little plastic that rotates on the very bottom of the steel bowl, the plastic that rotates inside the bowl had snapped, the plastic basically rotates to make sure all the coffee is all been grounded. But the customer service at mr coffee replaced the whole unit for free. But other then the plastic snapping, this is a great grinder, I love the settings it gives you. Hopefully mr coffee changes the plastic to a metal so you don't have to worry about it breaking.

I'm about to toss my second Mr. Coffee IDS77 grinder. The first one suffered a broken grinding blade after a year or so of use. After a disastrous experience with a burr grinder, I bought another IDS77. This one also lasted about a year--now the chamber maid gizmo, made out of plastic, that's supposed to help clean the grinds from the edges of the bowl, has broken in two places and the shafts look worn down. So I've been drinking shaved plastic along with my coffee! This is obviously a design flaw that numerous reviewers have pointed out. But the blade is riveted on top of it, so it can't be removed or replaced. And Mr. Coffee has not corrected the problem by substituting a metal chamber maid or just leaving it out of the product. I'll be buying a new grinder, and it won't be a Mr. Coffee. By the way, when it works it's fairly decent for a blade grinder. Noisy, but grinding time can be varied so you have some control over coarseness. We like a coarse french press grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder does a poor job at grinding coffee beans for a French press
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder does a poor job at grinding coffee beans for a French press. The grind is inconsistent on course with a mixture Expresso grind to whole beans left in the grinder after its timed grind. It always ends up making a mess on the while trying to empty the grinder.

I can recommend this for drip coffee machines, it seems to work beat for that type of grinding.

I bought a new electric percolator (I got tired of the lousy coffee from drip coffeemakers) and because I needed a coarser grind than that readily available in grocery stores, I decided I would grind my own coffee beans to make coffee in it. I purchased the Mr. Coffee IDS77 from a local store. I hated it; it only had 3 grind settings, it was not easy to use, I had to stand there and hold the button till it stopped, the cord wrap was a royal pain, and worst of all some beans were ground to a fine powder but it also left big unground chunks of coffee bean at the completion of the coarse-grind cycle - - yuck! And it was difficult for me to disassemble, clean, and reassemble with arthritic hands (lots of twisting involved).

After reading all the reviews here (thank you, fellow Amazon fans!) I ordered the Hamilton Beach 80374 Hands-Free for just a few more dollars and WHAT A DIFFERENCE! See my review at that product.

Needless to say, I am returning the Mr. Coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not as good as manual describes
reviews.reviewText: I had this grinder for a year before giving it away to a friend. I think that it does do a great job at grinding (but it's loud--I felt like I was waking up everyone in the teacher dorm each morning I used it!!) and all the different settings seem to yield appropriate grind sizes. The problem I had with it was the cleanup. The main reason I think I had problems was that the manual said not to use any beans with flavors...the flavored coffee beans leave a residue that is a little difficult to clean out. So that is my own fault but shouldn't a grinder be compatible with flavored beans? I think so! The other negative aspect was the fact that the "handy" pour spout was not handy at all. I would need to use a garbage can to ensure I was not going to dump coffee grounds all over the counter or even myself! It was still difficult to get all the grounds out without opening up the grinder and then I would still end up getting a little bit of the grounds on the counter. This could be significantly improved. One last thing...the cord doesn't really stay wrapped up very well. I think a model with a retractable cord would be better. I think I got mine for $15 at Wal-Mart.

reviews.reviewTitle: "I can Make Awesome Coffee At Home"!!!
reviews.reviewText: My Husband and I love this Mr. Coffee "12 CUP" Electric Coffee Grinder. W/Multi settings!!! We were blown away honestly. I like that I can make it for 4 cups or any amount you really need. We found if you keep the Grinder Clean we haven't had any problems. We are very happy customers

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful! Couldn't ask for a better grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I am a former barista and as such, I am very familiar with what type of grind should be produced and inconsistency etc and when I received this grinder for Christmas 2 years ago (I have the red one) I was a little skeptical that it wouldn't compare to my very high coffee standards.
I was pleasantly surprised! 2 years later it still works great and looks great in my red kitchen. You choose how many cups and what type of grind you want and it stops when it reaches that consistency. Even that works great and is great for my husband when he makes me a pot of coffee or french press because I know he can't mess it up.
It certainly isn't a $300 grinder but for the average consumer like myself, it gets the job done and does it well! Definitely would recommend this to my family and friends who are in the market for a new grinder or just have one that they aren't too happy with.

I use this to grind coffee for my french press. The grind is pretty uneven, there are almost always large fragments of coffee bean in the grounds. I mean, it works. If you're pressed for cash this is a practical grinder that isn't too expensive. I have had it six months now and it still works.

I mistakenly thought at first that the cable was ridiculously short, but then another reviewer here told me that you can indeed pull the cord out more. I was just afraid to pull too hard and break it.

reviews.reviewTitle: hard to empty and the chamber maid cleaning system doesn't do that great a job
reviews.reviewText:
Personally I think the design is very fussy, needlessly so. It seems hard to load, hard to empty and the chamber maid cleaning system doesn't do that great a job. It helps some <shrug>.
Whhen most of the coffee is ground very small, I find I still have some whole beans.
The grind selections don't seem to affect the reality of the grind much.
I'll be looking to replace this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Reasonably priced, works well, don't wash in dishwasher
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this grinder for a year now. It was reasonably priced and had the features I required which included dishwasher safe. The flip top lid is useless. Unless your beans are stale, fresh ground coffee will not just dump out it. You have to take the lid off to do that which isn't a big deal. Don't be to impressed with the words "Chamber Maid Cleaning System. This is a plastic basket within the grinder's cup that you have to push with your finger and it scrapes the sides clean. I assume this was a feature they added just to mark the price up another $1.

My one dissapointment with this is that if you do regularly wash in the top rack of your dishwasher, over time little bits of food collect in the underside of the cup and they can not escape even if you soak it later. I just close my eyes and pretend it's not there anymore until either the motor goes or the cup brakes (this type of plastic that if washed continuously in dishwasher usually lasts 1/5 - 2 years and then breaks) and I buy another model of grinder. So if this is something you would not ejoy just hand wash it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fail from box to trashcan in less than 2 months
reviews.reviewText:
Bought this at walmart in a pinch. Stupidly threw out receipt.

For the first two months it worked in a general sort of way. Despite pouring meticulously measured amounts and setting the device per the instructions, my coffee would be very inconsistently ground. As for removing the grounds, it is clunky, messy, and difficult to clean. Frankly, I'd probably have a better and more precise time of grinding my beans by beating the bag with a hammer.

The final insult came when one day I woke up, trudged to the cursed device, and observed that the annoying green lights that never turn off, were off. What? I fiddled with it for 20 minutes. Making sure it was clean, nothing obstructing anything. Tried other outlets. Nothing. It just died at some point in the last 24 hours. I'd say RIP but frankly I didn't like it enough to be so cordial.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: I gave it 2 stars not that i didnt like it but the longevity of it is bad. This grinder did work well until it stopped. Others say they had them for many years. But I had mine for about 1.5 yrs. which is not bad except I only used it about 20 times which makes it about $1.00 per grind. kind of expensive it u ask me. I don't know what happened it just quit working I think the motor burned out.I did fill it a little past the line but really u should be able to fill it to the top and not burn the motor out. Mr. coffee as usual (and I have had many of there coffee makers over the years) and my opinion is They make products to last just long enough that people will buy another one from them but not as long as things should last. Isn't that all manufactures these days, more research goes into how to make it die the day after the warranty is up instead of how can we make it last longer,

Burned out one day maybe lasted about a year, went to plug it in and it had no lights no grind, build quality is questionable, the maid cleaning system (plastic turning things inside the chamber) eventually all broke and had to be removed

no pre-warning it was going to fail, just poof one night worked fine, next day broken.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked OK when it did and just as easily as it would work
reviews.reviewText: Worked OK when it did and just as easily as it would work, it quit working yesterday. When it DID work, you had to split your grinding down to mini quantities. Very ineffective and a shame to have Mr. Coffee name associated with yet another piece of junk. I SWEAR, I will NEVER buy another Mr. Coffee product ever again
Ive been using this for a couple months now and it works like a charm. Love that it has a course grind setting for my French press. Easy and convenient.

It boasts an automatic timer that grinds your beans the right about of time then turns off. But it makes you hold down an uncomfortable lever contraption on the cap in order to make it turn on at all. It's feels clumsy when trying to dismantle the cap and put it back together. The chamber maid is neat, but doesn't get everything around the edges and will surely break eventually. The selection lights would continue to stay on after I was finished grinding so I had to unplug the device from the wall when not in use. The power chord is about a foot long!

I got this to replace a simple grind-in-the-cap style grinder that would make a mess putting the cap back on. The Mr. Coffee is neat because the grind device comes off so you have less potential for a mess. I use it to grind espresso and it's pretty hard to scoop coffee out of the deep container and worthless with the flip up cap on. The Chamber maid gets all in the way when trying to scoop as well. Taking the cap off can potentially create the same mess that my other grinder made.

I could hold my old grinder in my hand and shake it up and down during grinding to attempt to grind beans more evenly. This one is too big and doesn't fit good in your hand so you can't do that easily and it tends to grind the beans at the bottom more finely than those at the top. Then it turns off automatically because of the silly timer, when you don't want it do.

Neat idea, bad execution. I went back to my simple grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is so clunky and a real pain to ...
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is so clunky and a real pain to use. The chamber maid feature is a cheap plastic contraption inside that broke after a couple months use. I called mr. Coffee to possibly replace the part, but they said that part is no longer available. DONT BY THIS CLUNKY GRINDER. The company doesn't stand behind it and no longer produces replacement parts.

reviews.reviewTitle: The self cleaning ribs are stupid. They don't work and will eventually break
reviews.reviewText: The self cleaning ribs are stupid. They don't work and will eventually break. You can't press the button and let the coffee grinder do the work. You press and hold the button and it shuts off automatically. It misses whole beans. Not worth buying.

I received this coffee grinder as a Christmas gift and lasted about 11 months before the grinder blade chewed up and broke the plastic scraping blades on the inside. In the time I used the grinder I was never a big fan: It was loud, had an inconsistent grind, messy (that could be my fault, I'm messy in the kitchen).

I know I'm being very negative, but it is a serviceable, inexpensive grinder. It is not ideal for french presses. It might be good enough for coffee filters...that is, until it eats itself from the inside. It's probably great for herbs.

I don't think blade type grinders work as well as burr grinders, hence the 4 stars. Regardless, I really really like this one. I have found as I get older the last thing I want to do before I've had my coffee is to spend 5 Min. turning a crank.

Just bought this grinder (not off amazon). I'm not a coffee drinker so I can't base my review on its efficiency on coffee beans but to anyone out there looking for a really good flaxseed grinder then you've found it in this machine. I'm seriously amazed at how well it works. Flaxseeds are super tiny and I thought I would've needed a burr grinder but wanted to avoid the expense (cheapy I know). I took a chance, held my breath, crossed my fingers and made the purchase praying it would do the job...and it did. I'll post pics some time later but the grinder literally transformed the flaxseeds into the consistency of powder. In fact it looks like fine brown sugar. I used the grind setting 8 and the cup setting 6. Every single seed was ground. Now I was especially careful not to fill the plastic cup past the max fill limit. In fact I advise only filling it halfway below the max fill line. It places less stress on the machine and allows for optimum grinding. Disclaimer: the machine is obviously not designed as a flaxseed grinder. Use at your own discretion. I'm not encouraging its use outside of what it's manufactured for. If you purchase it to use as a flaxseed grinder you are fully responsible for it thereafter. Now that that's out of the way on to the cons. Cleaning the cup is a bit disturbing only because the blade part is not removable. You have to wash around it. Also there's a plastic frame thing inside of the cup that is also fixed in place and can't be taken out so god forbid any particles get trapped beneath it. Other than that, so far so good.

Yes, this machine does grind your coffee beans but does a terrible job at it. Regardless of how you have the settings, it is impossible to get any sort of uniform grind. I don't expect much for a cheap grinder but this is pretty bad. I've included a photo as to how my beans end up. As you can see, there are beans of all shapes and sizes. That's how they are EVERY time. You have been warned.

reviews.reviewTitle: Over 10 years and still use it every day!!
reviews.reviewText: I am looking for a second coffee grinder and am amazed that this one (exactly the same that I can tell) is still being sold. I bought my first one in 04-05 and we use it at least once every single day. It works flawlessly... Best bang for the buck there is in the coffee grinder world

reviews.reviewTitle: Total crap! This thing is nothing more that a miniature ...
reviews.reviewText: Total crap! This thing is nothing more that a miniature blender that doesn't do as claimed. It leaves chunks of bean in what is essentially a chopped up mess. Mine went to the dumpster.

I just started grinding my own coffee about 10 mths. ago,so i saw thw reviews on this coffee grinder,I thought this will be the one! After 10 mths.,it just died. Went to do some griunding,and nothing. The lights indicating the amount of cups and the courseness were lit,but went to push the button to grind and nothing. I will now look fpr a burr grinder,which is supposed to give a much better tasting coffee. And also,there was a lot of clean-up after grinding was completed

Great grinder if you like your ground coffee getting trapped inside the grinder and making a huge mess. Besides being ugly and clunky, this is the most ill engineered appliance I've ever used. It has plastic ridges inside the chamber that make either scooping or pouring the grounds a frustrating, wasteful and messy act of self-defeat. I curse this grinder everyday and am now shopping on amazon for a simple krups like I used to have. No mess, no fuss.

Did anyone at Mr. Coffee actually try to use this thing to grind coffee? It's incomprehensible to me that the would have and decided it was 'good enough.' I guess that's why they added the silly lights and different modes -- You won't use them though, you'll be lucky to recover your coffee from the unit. 16.99/pound coffee forever lost to all those nooks and crannies forever inaccessible to even the most determined scoop or spoon.

Additionally, the top has 2 weird flap lids that don't make any sense and add to the mess. And the screw close mechanism is equally horrible and unintuitive. Just try aligning the grooves and turning in place before grinding -- is it closed? who knows?

Mr. coffee....time to pass that title on, you're senile.

reviews.reviewTitle: Coffee to grind my coffee for many years and with this new one will continue to happily grind for many hours of coffee enjoyment
reviews.reviewText: this is a replacement item . I have used Mr. Coffee to grind my coffee for many years and with this new one will continue to happily grind for many hours of coffee enjoyment. I took the old one and turned it into an herb grinder. Works great that too !. excellent value for the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Complete POS. I've not bought 2 of these, ...
reviews.reviewText: Complete POS. I've not bought 2 of these, and neither lasted more than 1 month, and they were not heavily used. Save your money.

reviews.reviewTitle: PRODUCT REVISION? Non-User-Serviceable Thermal Fuse, Quick Failure
reviews.reviewText:
Using the "fine" setting the grinder died before completing a single bag of beans. I didn't stuff it to capacity, I was gradually working through the beans and refilling the bag.
